However, there are significant concerns regarding the resolving power of ITS for closely related species (Cai et al., 2009; Crouch et al., 2009b). Recognizing the limitations of ITS and similar markers has led to an increasing necessity for the development and use of more informative loci. Molecular phylogenetic analyses using multilocus datasets are now providing an objective approach to determining species boundaries.

query: Why is it bad if fruit diseases happen before or after harvesting?
retrieved_context: Two distinct types of diseases occur: those affecting developing fruit in the field (preharvest) and those damaging mature fruit during storage (postharvest). The ability to cause latent or quiescent infections has categorized Colletotrichum among the most important postharvest pathogens. Species of the pathogen predominantly appear on aboveground plant tissues; however, belowground organs, such as roots and tubers, may also be affected.

On certain fruits, such as apple and blueberry (Vaccinium spp.), members of the C. acutatum species complex cause both pre-harvest and post-harvest diseases (Milholland, 1995; Jones et al., 1996; Shi et al., 1996). On these plants, asymptomatic, quiescent infections occur on unripe fruit, developing into necrotic lesions as the fruit ripens (Alkan et al., 2015). There are many other examples of post-harvest decay in fruits like peaches (Prunus persica), almonds (Prunus dulcis), avocado (Persea americana), mango (Mangifera indica), papaya (Carica papaya), and guava (Psidium guajava) that stem from quiescent infections that began in the field (Agostini et al., 1992; Freeman and Shabi, 1996; Smith, 1998; Afanador-Kafuri et al., 2003).

On some hosts, such as apple and blueberry, C. acutatum poses a preharvest problem and also acts as a postharvest pathogen. Quiescent infections occurring before harvest develop as the fruit ripens, leading to ripe rot of blueberry and bitter rot of apple after harvest. Postharvest symptoms can also emerge with anthracnose diseases affecting peaches, almonds, and other stone fruits. Additionally, many tropical fruits like avocado, mango, papaya, and guava can suffer from postharvest decay due to quiescent infections established in the field.

Papaya is a climacteric fleshy fruit typically harvested at the pre-climacteric stage, meaning that ripening begins after harvest, resulting in a relatively short shelf life. During this period, several fruit rot pathogens, including Colletotrichum spp., can cause damage. Although papaya anthracnose symptoms can occur in both fruits and leaves, Colletotrichum infections are usually more severe in fruits. Refrigerated papayas are particularly susceptible to disease; therefore, fruits intended for export may develop anthracnose symptoms as they ripen.

Anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum species, is a significant postharvest disease of bananas. These pathogens can infect banana plants in plantations and remain latent. Bananas are often harvested before ripening, and as they ripen during storage, anthracnose symptoms manifest as brown or black lesions. These lesions can enlarge, become sunken, and produce spore masses. Mechanical damage, such as wounds and scratches on the banana peel from handling and transportation, exacerbates the symptoms [101], severely affecting the quality of bananas for both export and local markets.

Fruit Hemibiotrophic Lifestyle (Blueberry, Apple, Stone Fruit): Fruit decays represent a common lifestyle of C. acutatum, leading to diseases such as blueberry ripe rot, apple bitter rot, and anthracnose of peach, along with numerous anthracnose diseases in subtropical and tropical fruits. In cases like bitter rot of apple and ripe rot of blueberry, acervuli are produced abundantly on mature fruit. Conidia from these acervuli are splash-dispersed, germinate to form appressoria, and establish quiescent infections on fruit, as demonstrated in peaches. These diseases can occur both in the field and post-harvest. However, most quiescent infections develop throughout the growing season. For blueberries, C. acutatum is also known to attack young leaves and other tissues, although this is rare. Thus, conidia from acervuli on leaves and decaying fruit may serve as a source of inoculum for other fruits, and the pathogen can survive as appressoria in bud scales and dead fruiting twigs. In apples, the source of inoculum is less obvious, as C. acutatum only causes disease on fruit. The fungus appears to be widespread in orchards and is easily isolated from both healthy and damaged tissue. In Michigan, where bitter rot is rare, C. acutatum remains prevalent in apple orchards and is commonly isolated, suggesting that it survives and reproduces as an epiphyte or endophyte, akin to the epiphytic–short necrotroph lifestyle.

Colletotrichum spp. are frequently linked with various citrus diseases worldwide, including PFD (Post Fruit Drop) on sweet orange, KLA (Kumquat Leaf Anthracnose), and post-harvest anthracnose across different hosts.

The primary means to reduce the buildup of anthracnose fruit rot in the field is to harvest fruit frequently and remove all rotten fruit from the field. Following severe infections early in the fruiting season, all infected fruit should be stripped from the plants and removed from the field. Infected areas of a field should be harvested last in the day, or workers should wash up and change into clean clothes when they must enter uninfected areas of the field after harvesting areas where fruit rot is present.

The main objectives of this study were to assess the potential for cross-inoculation, survival, and pathogenicity of C. acutatum on strawberry and other plants that may serve as a primary inoculum source under greenhouse conditions.

Since its first report in the United States in 1931, strawberry anthracnose has spread globally, resulting in devastating economic, social, and ecological consequences. In many ways, producing organic strawberries is largely impractical because of this disease. Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries have been extensively characterized. This review aims to provide an accurate inventory of these species by revisiting their discovery history over the past 90 years. A total of 23 Colletotrichum species, clustered into five species complexes and two singleton taxa, have been accepted as strawberry pathogens with a global occurrence illustrated. While most studies have focused on comparisons of distantly related lineages, they also highlight the necessity for higher resolution taxonomic sampling to better understand the evolution of fungal genomes and their possible associations with phenotypic traits such as host range, pathogenic lifestyle, and reproductive strategy. In this context, the C. acutatum species complex serves as an excellent model system, offering a variety of closely related evolutionary lineages with different phenotypic characteristics. An example of this is the switch between mono- and dicotyledonous hosts that occurred in clade 5 (Figure 1). Comparative genomics and transcriptomics of late-diverging species adapted to different hosts may enhance our understanding of the genomic bases involved in host switching. Another notable case is the host specialization of certain lineages, such as C. lupini. The biological diversity of the C. acutatum species complex, coupled with the presence of closely related species exhibiting varied characteristics such as host range, mating behavior, and spectrum, makes C. acutatum a suitable model for investigating genomic signatures associated with changes in crucial phenotypic traits of fungal plants.

Colletotrichum spp. infect a wide diversity of hosts, causing plant diseases in many economically important crops worldwide. The genus contains approximately 189 species organized into at least 11 major phylogenetic lineages, also known as species complexes. The Colletotrichum acutatum species complex is a diverse yet relatively closely related group of plant pathogenic fungi within this genus. Within this complex, we find a wide variety of important traits such as host range and preference, mode of reproduction, and differences in strategies used to infect their hosts. Research on fungal comparative genomics has attempted to find correlations in these traits and patterns of gene family evolution; however, such studies typically compare fungi from different genera or even different fungal orders. The C. acutatum species complex contains most of this diversity within a group of relatively closely related species.

Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).

Abstract: Colletotrichum acutatum is recognized as a significant anthracnose pathogen affecting a broad range of host plants globally. Numerous studies have reported subgroups within the C. acutatum species complex. A multilocus molecular phylogenetic analysis (ITS, ACT, TUB2, CHS-1, GAPDH, HIS3) involving 331 strains previously identified as C. acutatum and related taxa—spanning various hosts across diverse geographic regions—confirmed the previously recognized molecular groups and identified several novel taxa. Thirty-one species are accepted, of which 21 have not been previously recognized. Colletotrichum orchidophilum clusters basal to the C. acutatum species complex. This complex exhibits high phenotypic diversity, with some species showing preferences for specific hosts or geographic regions, while others are plurivorous and found in multiple areas. In this study, only C. salicis and C. rhombiforme formed sexual morphs in culture; however, sexual morphs have been documented from other taxa, particularly in laboratory crosses, with evidence of hybridization between different species. A new species, C. pseudoacutatum, was also described, resembling C. acutatum but not belonging to its species complex.

The general evolutionary trend emerging in the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex indicates that distinct populations are undergoing significant changes in their host association patterns. This may suggest a role of behavioral switching in mating and changes in host associations. The occurrence of heterothallism appears to influence host range diversity, while isolates capable of homothallism, such as C. salicis and C. phormii, exhibit a narrower host range. This evolutionary trend suggests that the capacity of populations to exchange genetic information leads to genomic rearrangements, thereby increasing genome plasticity and expanding the host spectrum of this pathogen.

Discussion: Recent phylogenetic studies of the genus Colletotrichum have revealed clustering in 11 major clades, including significant species complexes such as C. acutatum, C. boninense, C. gloeosporioides, and C. truncatum. These studies facilitate the differentiation and description of numerous taxa.

query: Are there pathogens capable of infecting multiple types of crops?
retrieved_context: Filamentous fungi of the genus Colletotrichum and its teleomorph Glomerella are considered major plant pathogens worldwide. They cause significant economic damage to crops in tropical, subtropical, and temperate regions. Cereals, legumes, ornamentals, vegetables, and fruit trees may be seriously affected by these pathogens. Although many cultivated fruit crops are infected by Colletotrichum species, the most significant economic losses occur when the fruiting stage is attacked. Colletotrichum species cause typical disease symptoms known as anthracnose, characterized by sunken necrotic tissue where orange conidial masses are produced. Anthracnose diseases can appear in both developing and mature plant tissues.

Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds is a common pathogen affecting a wide range of crops and non-cultivated plant species. The fungus is cosmopolitan and causes significant crop losses annually. Symptoms of the disease can include fruit rots, as well as shoot, leaf, and flower blights. Common hosts encompass many dicotyledonous plants, including strawberries, apples, citrus, and stone fruits; serious diseases have also been reported on leatherleaf ferns and pines. Notably, there are no known reports of C. acutatum affecting grasses. While well-documented from agricultural hosts, recent findings of C. acutatum in a moribund sea turtle and a native forest suggest it may inhabit other less-studied niches.

query: What implications does the new species C. alatae have for managing anthracnose in yam cultivation in tropical climates?
retrieved_context: Anthracnose diseases of yam are prevalent in all regions where the host is cultivated (e.g., Winch et al. 1984; Prasad & Singh 1960; Singh et al. 1966; Abang et al. 2002, 2003). Isolates from diseased yam leaves exhibit significant morphological (Winch et al. 1984) and genetic diversity (Abang et al. 2002). Both authors employed a broad species concept, grouping all yam-sourced isolates under the single name C. gloeosporioides. In this paper, we recognize part of that diversity as representing a distinct species, newly described as C. alatae. The type specimen of C. alatae aligns with the SGG (slow growing grey) group identified by Abang et al. (2002), which was noted to be more pathogenic to yam than other morphological and genetic groups recognized within C. gloeosporioides. This includes Nigerian isolates from Abang et al. (2002), as well as isolates from Barbados (SAS8 and SAS9 from Sreenivasaprasad et al. 1996), Guadeloupe (GenBank accession GQ495617), and India (CBS 304.67 and GenBank accession FJ940734), with no other host isolates identified.

Several names have been historically assigned to Colletotrichum specimens associated with anthracnose of yam stems and leaves, including Gloeosporium pestis Massee, G. dioscoreae Sawada (nom. inval.; no Latin diagnosis), Colletotrichum dioscoreae Av.-Saccá 1917, and C. dioscoreae Tehon 1933. Additionally, Gloeosporium bomplandii Speg. was described from a host ambiguously identified as Dioscorea. Due to the broad genetic diversity among Colletotrichum species associated with diseased yam, the absence of cultures from these early type specimens, and uncertainty regarding the diversity they correspond to, we have opted not to apply these historical names to our newly recognized yam-specialized pathogen. The relationship between the post-harvest tuber rot, referred to as dead skin disease of yam (Abang et al. 2003; Green & Simmons 1994), and the Colletotrichum population associated with diseased foliage remains unclear.

retrieved_context: In 2021, Shanghai experienced its longest summer, lasting 162 days until mid-October, which is 52 days longer than the summer 60 years ago. This extended summer contributed to the outbreak of several diseases, including anthracnose crown rot, leading to increased mortality after transplanting in strawberry production fields. It is concerning to speculate that global warming may exacerbate the threat of anthracnose to strawberry production. However, changes in temperature and other climate factors can have positive, neutral, or negative effects on disease development, depending on the specific responses of the disease triangle to these variations (Velásquez et al. 2018). In an era of anthropogenic habitat modification and climate change, we must consider how to mitigate the impacts of global warming on sustainable strawberry development.

Abundant anthracnose infestation was evident in many nurseries during the summers of 1995 and 1996, resulting in a massive collapse of transplants in soil-fumigated fields. Plants that died within the first 3 to 4 weeks after transplantation are routinely replaced with new transplants. Moreover, as the plants are aligned with the drip irrigation system, the replacement plants are often placed in the same slots previously occupied by those that died, thus exposing them to the soilborne inoculum. Due to infestation in the nurseries, many farmers replanted infected but symptomless transplants in the same plots without refumigating the soil, significantly increasing the inoculum density. This situation was reflected in the high levels of C. acutatum populations in the rhizosphere of plants growing in naturally infested field soils. The unusual symptoms of root necrosis caused by C. acutatum may have resulted from root exposure to high inoculum density in the soil, compounded by the repeated use of contaminated propagation material. Stunted plants with decayed root systems were not infected by systemic invasion from inoculum originating from the crown (Fig. 1). While root necrosis caused by C. acutatum has not been widely reported, lesion development has been observed on roots following artificial dip inoculations (7). Furthermore, the pathogen was found to survive for up to 9 months in California soils (8) and to overwinter in fruit located above and below the soil surface in Ohio (37). Survival studies conducted in Israel indicated that populations of C. acutatum in artificially inoculated fruit buried for various periods in the soil decline rapidly (3 to 6 months) to untraceable levels (S. Freeman, unpublished data). Therefore, the likelihood of persistent soil contamination by a soilborne inoculum of C. acutatum appears low, especially since soil fumigation is a standard practice.

From May to September 1995, a severe outbreak of strawberry anthracnose was observed in several strawberry-growing nurseries in Israel. Following transplantation to production fields during September and October, entire beds of strawberry plants collapsed. Typical anthracnose symptoms observed from November 1995 to June 1996 included crown rot, flower blight, and green and ripe fruit rot. This marked the first record of strawberry anthracnose in Israel. Furthermore, in at least four production fields in the same region, hundreds of plants developed symptoms of stunting and chlorosis, which are atypical of strawberry anthracnose. When these plants were uprooted, most of their roots were dark brown and decayed. Colletotrichum was readily isolated from these samples.

The strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa), a small fruit crop, was introduced to Bangladesh in 1996 from Japan and the USA, gaining notable acceptance among both growers and consumers. However, as acreage expanded, anthracnose crown rot (ACR) has emerged as a significant challenge for strawberry producers. In March 2016, typical symptoms of ACR were observed in the 'Strawberry Festival' cultivar at a farmer's field in the Rajshahi district of Bangladesh. Symptoms were apparent in approximately 10% of the plants, manifesting as wilting of entire plants during the heat of the day and flagging of young leaves, resembling water deficiency.

Anthracnose is a key limiting factor for strawberry production in Taiwan and many other regions. Outbreaks of anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and fields have caused yield losses of up to 50-80%. This study demonstrated the diversity of pathogenic Colletotrichum species associated with strawberry in Taiwan. The findings provide precise information about pathogen identity, which is valuable for screening resistant varieties and developing effective disease management strategies. Regardless of whether inoculated on wounded or non-wounded leaves, the predominant pathogen C. siamense caused larger lesions at 30°C than at 25°C, which is significant in subtropical Taiwan and similar areas. No significant difference was observed between the mycelial growth rates of C. siamense at 25°C, 28°C, and 30°C; hence, the higher disease severity at 30°C may be due to reduced resistance of strawberry plants to anthracnose at elevated temperatures. In Taiwan, the susceptible cultivar Taoyuan No. 1 has been widely cultivated for over 30 years. Developing temperature-independent resistant cultivars will be crucial for strawberry breeding programs in Taiwan and other tropical and subtropical regions. Future work will focus on monitoring pathogen population changes, investigating fungicide sensitivity levels of different Colletotrichum species, and developing molecular detection methods to assist in producing strawberry seedlings free of latent infection by major Colletotrichum species.

The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.

Under suitable environmental conditions, anthracnose can lead to significant yield losses (Henz et al. 1992). Infected strawberries may develop lesions on the petiole and crown, potentially resulting in plant collapse and death. In nurseries, lesions can form on stolons, leading to the wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants (Freeman and Katan 1997). Infected transplants can spread the disease from the nursery to the field, where typical symptoms of anthracnose manifest as irregular black leaf spots, crown rot, flower blight, and fruit rot (Howard et al. 1992).

An internal symptom of a crown infection is red discoloration, typically extending in a “V” shape from the side of the crown toward the center. Other pathogens such as Colletotrichum gloeosporioides and C. acutatum also cause anthracnose diseases in strawberries.

query: Why is Colletotrichum siamense considered a significant pathogen in Taiwan's strawberry production?

Outbreaks of anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and fields have caused yield losses of up to 50-80%. This study demonstrated the diversity of pathogenic Colletotrichum species associated with strawberry in Taiwan. The findings provide precise information about pathogen identity, which is valuable for screening resistant varieties and developing effective disease management strategies. Regardless of whether inoculated on wounded or non-wounded leaves, the predominant pathogen C. siamense caused larger lesions at 30°C than at 25°C, which is significant in subtropical Taiwan and similar areas. No significant difference was observed between the mycelial growth rates of C. siamense at 25°C, 28°C, and 30°C; hence, the higher disease severity at 30°C may be due to reduced resistance of strawberry plants to anthracnose at elevated temperatures. In Taiwan, the susceptible cultivar Taoyuan No. 1 has been widely cultivated for over 30 years. Developing temperature-independent resistant cultivars will be crucial for strawberry breeding programs in Taiwan and other tropical and subtropical regions. Future work will focus on monitoring pathogen population changes, investigating fungicide sensitivity levels of different Colletotrichum species, and developing molecular detection methods to assist in producing strawberry seedlings free of latent infection by major Colletotrichum species.

C. boninense, C. fructicola, C. siamense, and C. karstii have been isolated from diverse plants other than strawberry in various countries and regions. In Taiwan, C. fructicola has been reported as an anthracnose pathogen in mango, wax apple, and chili; C. siamense in lychee, star fruit, and mango; C. karstii in passion fruit; and C. boninense in pitaya. Previous studies have demonstrated that Colletotrichum species from strawberry are pathogenic to other crops and even weeds. For example, C. acutatum could infect pepper, eggplant, tomato, and bean, and could also latently colonize weeds such as Vicia spp. and Conyza spp. In one study, C. fructicola was frequently isolated from leaves of Amaranthus blitum, and artificial inoculation of C. fructicola caused brown leaf spots on A. blitum. To determine whether weed control is necessary to minimize primary infection in the field, it is important to investigate whether the five Colletotrichum species identified could colonize weeds commonly found in and around strawberry fields in Taiwan. More sampling and artificial inoculation assays will be needed to understand the host range of the newly identified species C. miaoliense.

There exists high genome plasticity in Colletotrichum species, enabling them to adapt powerfully (Gan et al. 2021). Within the genus Colletotrichum, C. gloeosporioides s.l. is the most diversified complex, comprising as many as 57 species. This complex has been considered a heterogeneous species aggregate affecting over 700 plant species (O'Connell et al. 2012; Talhinhas and Baroncelli 2021; Farr and Rossman 2022). The most prevalent species in Chinese strawberry fields, C. siamense and C. fructicola, belong to C. gloeosporioides s.l. They are the two most frequently occurring Colletotrichum species globally, with significantly more records in Asia compared to other continents. Both species can affect more than 70 genera of hosts widely distributed across the phylogenetic tree of angiosperms. Compared to C. fructicola, C. siamense infects significantly more plants, including one gymnosperm. Notably, some Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries can also infect members of other kingdoms beyond plant hosts. For instance, the prevalent C. siamense in strawberry fields has been reported as a human pathogen, causing skin lesions in immunocompromised individuals (Werbel et al. 2019). C. truncatum has also been identified as an opportunistic human pathogen (Valenzuela-Lopez et al. 2018), while C. dematium has been reported to infect human tissues such as the cornea (Talhinhas and Baroncelli 2021). These associations between strawberry pathogens and humans highlight the importance of biosecurity in scientific research and agricultural practices.

Through multilocus sequence analysis coupled with morphological characterization, recent studies have identified many additional Colletotrichum species associated with strawberry, namely C. acutatum, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii (C. acutatum species complex), as well as C. aenigma, C. changpingense, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. siamense, and C. theobromicola (syn. C. fragariae) (C. gloeosporioides species complex), and C. boninense (C. boninense species complex). Although strawberry is of great economic importance in Taiwan and anthracnose has become more destructive in the past decade, the pathogen population in Taiwan has not been systematically investigated. The causal agents of strawberry anthracnose were previously reported to include C. gloeosporioides, C. dematium, C. fragariae, and C. acutatum, but information about the isolation, pathogenicity, morphology, and genetic sequences of these species is insufficient for accurate species identification. Recently, based on the analysis of multiple gene sequences, we identified C. siamense as the pathogen causing anthracnose crown rot.

Abstract: Fragaria ananassa (common name: strawberry) is a globally cultivated hybrid species belonging to the Rosaceae family. Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato (s.l.) is considered the second most economically important pathogen worldwide affecting strawberries. A collection of 148 Colletotrichum spp. isolates, including 67 C. acutatum s.l. isolates associated with the phytosanitary history of UK strawberry production, was used to characterize multilocus genetic variation of this pathogen in the UK, relative to additional reference isolates representing a worldwide sampling of the fungus diversity. Evidence indicates that three different species—C. nymphaeae, C. godetiae, and C. fioriniae—are associated with strawberry production in the UK, corresponding to previously designated genetic groups A2, A4, and A3, respectively. Among these species, 12 distinct haplotypes were identified, suggesting multiple introductions into the country. A subset of isolates was also used to assess aggressiveness in causing disease on strawberry plants and fruits. Isolates belonging to C. nymphaeae, C. godetiae, and C. fioriniae, representative of the UK anthracnose pathogen populations, showed variation in their aggressiveness. Among the three species, C. nymphaeae and C. fioriniae appeared to be more aggressive compared to C. godetiae. This study highlights the genetic and pathogenic heterogeneity of the C. acutatum s.l. populations introduced into the UK linked to strawberry production.

In summary, a total of 23 Colletotrichum species have been accepted as strawberry pathogens, including nine species from the C. gloeosporioides complex (C. aenigma, C. alienum, C. changpingense, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides s.s., C. kahawae, C. siamense, C. viniferum, and C. theobromicola), seven species from the C. acutatum complex (C. acutatum s.s., C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. miaoliense, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii), two from the C. boninense complex (C. boninense s.s. and C. karstii), two from the C. dematium complex (C. lineola and C. dematium s.s.), and one from the C. truncatum complex (C. truncatum s.s.), as well as the two singletons C. nigrum and C. coccodes. Optimal markers for identifying distinct Colletotrichum species can be found in recent publications (Vieira et al., 2020; Bhunjun et al., 2021; Jayawardene et al., 2021). Undoubtedly, the catalog of Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries will expand in the future.

In America, where strawberry is widely cultivated, the diversity of strawberry pathogens is significant. In Canada, three species—C. fructicola (Weir et al. 2012), C. nymphaeae, and C. lineola (Jayawardena et al. 2016b)—were reported to infect strawberries. In the USA, at least six Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberry have been identified, including the dominant C. nymphaeae (Wang et al. 2019), along with C. simmondsii (Faedda et al. 2011), C. siamense (Adhikari et al. 2019; Eaton et al. 2021; Oliveira et al. 2022), the less prevalent C. fioriniae (Wang et al. 2019; Eaton et al. 2021), C. fructicola, and C. theobromicola (Weir et al. 2012; Oliveira et al. 2022). In Mexico, only Colletotrichum spp. at the genus level have been reported (Alvarez 1976; Rojas-Flores et al. 2019). C. nymphaeae infecting strawberry has also been recorded in Colombia and Costa Rica (Baroncelli et al. 2015). In Brazil, C. siamense (Capobiango et al. 2016) and C. karstii (Soares et al. 2021) were identified as pathogens. In Argentina, only the Colletotrichum species complexes (C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides) have been reported as infecting strawberries (Mináco et al. 2000; Ramallo et al. 2000).

Strawberry anthracnose is a significant disease in China, leading to considerable economic losses. Several species of Colletotrichum are recognized as pathogens of strawberry. A survey of strawberry fields across eight provinces in China was conducted to identify the causal agents of this disease. The disease primarily manifests as crown rot, causing plant wilting and death during the nursery stage and after transplanting in greenhouses, making anthracnose a major threat to strawberry production and quality.

To address this challenge, it is urgent to investigate the temperature adaptation of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries, particularly the prevalent ones like C. siamense and C. fructicola, focusing on their life cycles and pathogenesis. For effective control of anthracnose crown rot, developing disease-resistant strawberry varieties is essential. Resistance to crown anthracnose rot, combined with enhanced tolerance to high temperatures, should be a primary objective for strawberry breeders. Under global warming, significant latitudinal range shifts of plant pathogens have been observed, indicating that migration, rather than in situ adaptation to new climates, is the dominant response of pathogen populations to changing climates. Frequent host jumps and transitions facilitate the emergence of new fungal pathogens (Bebber et al. 2013; Chaloner et al. 2020). The evolution and flexibility of both temperature responses and host ranges among destructive Colletotrichum spp. contribute to their spread, invasion, and threat to strawberry production. Therefore, ongoing attention should be paid to changes in the biodiversity of fungal causal agents and their host ranges.

The prevalence of Colletotrichum spp. pathogenic to strawberries in China has become a significant concern, as China has been the largest strawberry producer in the world since 2010, according to annual statistical data from the Strawberry Division of the Chinese Society for Horticultural Science. In 2021, strawberry growers on the Chinese mainland planted 173,333 hectares and produced five million tons of fruit (Zhang 2021). The diverse cultivation practices and climate conditions in China have favored a high biodiversity of various pathogens affecting strawberries.

The Colletotrichum acutatum species complex is a diverse yet relatively closely related group of plant pathogenic fungi within this genus. Within this complex, we find a wide variety of important traits such as host range and preference, mode of reproduction, and differences in strategies used to infect their hosts. Research on fungal comparative genomics has attempted to find correlations in these traits and patterns of gene family evolution; however, such studies typically compare fungi from different genera or even different fungal orders. A similar situation applies to safflower (Carthamus tinctorius), where only strains of C. chrysanthemi were pathogenic to safflower. Strains genetically close but belonging to different species were not pathogenic on the same host (Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005; Baroncelli et al., 2015a). Other members of the species complex with a strong relationship to specific hosts include C. phormii, pathogenic to Phormium spp., and C. tamarilloi, the causal agent of tamarillo (Solanum betaceum) anthracnose (Baroncelli, 2012; Damm et al., 2012).

Three isolates of C. miaoliense were collected from Miaoli County and Nantou County, Taiwan. Multi-locus analysis revealed that C. miaoliense forms a robust clade distinct from other known species in the C. acutatum species complex. Among the six Colletotrichum species in this complex (C. acutatum, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii) identified as anthracnose pathogens of strawberry, C. miaoliense is most closely related phylogenetically to C. nymphaeae and C. simmondsii. Morphologically, C. miaoliense differs from C. nymphaeae (CBS 515.78) in conidial size (16.1 × 2.3 – 4.9 × 0.7 μm versus 14.2 × 1.1 – 4.1 × 0.34 μm), conidial shape (one end round and the other rounded to acute, contrasting with the new species where both ends are acute), and appressoria size (8.7 × 2.5 – 5.5 × 1.0 μm versus 7.5 × 1.0 μm).

Phylogenetic analyses using molecular markers have revealed that many members of the genus Colletotrichum can be grouped into independent lineages with similar evolutionary histories (Cai et al. 2011). Several of these lineages have now been systematically classified as species complexes comprising closely related sibling species (Weir et al. 2012). Many species within the C. gloeosporioides species complex have previously been classified as C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, largely based on morphological characteristics and known host range (Hyde et al. 2009). Additionally, the study by Weir et al. (2012) showed that ITS sequences, which have long been used to classify fungal species, are not very reliable in distinguishing different species within this species complex. However, different species do not require the same level of control when encountered in the field (Prihastuti et al. 2009).

Considering the frequency with which strains from the C. acutatum species complex are encountered and their pathogenicity to a wide range of crop plants, it would be surprising if earlier names for C. acutatum did not exist. Walker et al. (1991) found that C. xanthii (Halsted 1893) was synonymous with C. acutatum based on morphological criteria, but no authentic sequences are available, and it is currently unclear which clade this species fits into. At that time, there was no interest among Colletotrichum researchers to replace the name C. acutatum, and now the name is so widely used that a change would likely not gain recognition. Other older taxa have been recognized as belonging to the C. acutatum complex, but as close relatives rather than formal synonyms. Colletotrichum lupini was found to be an independent taxon within the C. acutatum complex by Nirenberg et al. (2002), rather than belonging to the C. gloeosporioides aggregate, as assumed by Yang & Sweetingham (1998) and Elmer et al. (2001). Farr et al. (2006) found C. phormii (based on Fusarium phormii, Hennings 1898) to be closely related to C. acutatum and noted that older reports of C. gloeosporioides as pathogens of Phormium could actually refer to C. phormii as well.

Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).

Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose in chili have previously been identified as C. acutatum (characterized by straight conidia with acute ends), C. gloeosporioides (straight conidia with obtuse ends), and C. truncatum (falcate conidia) (Than et al. 2008; Mongkolporn et al. 2010). However, recent multigene phylogenetic analyses have revealed that C. acutatum is a species complex (the acutatum complex) consisting of 34 closely related species (Marin-Felix et al. 2017), with seven species identified as responsible for anthracnose in chili (Mongkolporn and Taylor 2018). Similarly, C. gloeosporioides has been found to be a complex of 38 closely related species (Marin-Felix et al. 2017), with nine species identified as pathogens of chili (Mongkolporn and Taylor 2018). Morphological traits are insufficient to differentiate many species with straight conidia, particularly those in the acutatum and gloeosporioides complexes affecting chili. Thus, multigene phylogenetic analyses are essential for accurate species identification (De Silva et al. 2017a).

query: Can varying levels of calcium nitrate improve the resistance of tomato seedlings to Fusarium oxysporum in peat-vermiculite mixtures?
retrieved_context: Abstract: Media and nutrient variables were investigated to develop methods for reducing the incidence and severity of Fusarium crown rot caused by Fusarium oxysporum Schlecht. f. sp. radicis-lycopersici Jarvis & Shoemaker (FORL), which poses a significant challenge for tomato (Lycopersicon esculentum Mill.) cultivation. Root-dip inoculated seedlings were transplanted into trays filled with a 1:1 mixture of Canadian peat and vermiculite. These media were prepared using factorial combinations of calcium carbonate (CaCO₃) at rates of 0.75 or 3.0 kg·m⁻³, calcium nitrate [Ca(NO₃)₂] or ammonium sulfate [(NH₄)₂SO₄] (each providing 225 mg N/liter), and sodium chloride (NaCl) at either 0 or 2000 mg Na/liter as experimental treatments.

Abstract: This study evaluates how host nutritional variables affect the severity of crown and root rot in tomatoes caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycopersici. Tomato seedlings (Lycopersicon esculentum Mill., cv. Bonnie Best) were grown in a pathogen-infested, soilless rockwool system in a greenhouse, using a nutrient solution with varied macro- and microelement concentrations. Disease severity was assessed after two weeks with an index ranging from 0 to 4, and plant fresh weight was measured. Regression analysis showed that disease severity significantly increased with ammonium-nitrogen sources, including NH4Cl, (NH4)6Mo7O24, and (NH4)2SO4, along with NaH2PO4·H2O, Fe-EDDHA, and MnSO4. Conversely, nitrate-nitrogen (Ca(NO3)2·4H2O) and CuSO4·5H2O reduced disease severity. Low rates of NH4NO3 (39 to 79 mg·L–1 N) were beneficial, but levels above 100 mg·L–1 N exacerbated the issue. MgSO4·7H2O had no impact on disease. Notably, plant growth was inversely related to disease severity, and mineral fertilizers did not alter the pH of the nutrient solution. This information provides insights into the environmental factors influencing plant-pathogen interactions and can guide management strategies for Fusarium crown and root rot through host nutrition.

Two-week-old seedlings of the ‘Walter’ tomato variety were root-dip inoculated in Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycopersici (FORL) inoculum prepared by blending potato glucose agar cultures in sterile deionized water, diluting to a final concentration of 5 × 10^6 spores per milliliter. The root dip also involved crowns and a portion of the hypocotyl. The inoculated seedlings, 15 per container, were transplanted into plastic trays measuring 18.5 × 24.5 × 2.5 cm, containing approximately 0.002 m³ of a mix of 1 part Canadian peat to 1 part vermiculite. The medium was amended with 1.5 kg of a Perk micronutrient mix (Vigoro Industries, Fairview Heights, Ill.) and 3.0 kg of single superphosphate per cubic meter. Factorial combinations of powdered CaCO3 (0.75 or 3.0 kg·m³), solutions of Ca(NO3)2 or (NH4)2SO4 (each at 225 mg N/liter), and NaCl at either 0 or 204 mg Na/liter were used as experimental treatments. Calcium carbonate was included in the dry mix, while 200 ml of solutions of the nitrogen sources and NaCl were applied to the trays before planting the inoculated or non-inoculated seedlings. This application was repeated weekly until the end of the experiment.

The form of nitrogen significantly influenced both the severity of Fusarium crown and root rot and the growth of tomato seedlings in a soilless rockwool system (Fig. 1). Increasing concentrations of nitrate-N reduced disease severity and improved plant growth compared to ammonium forms. Both ammonium sulfate and ammonium chloride produced similar responses, indicating that NH4+ was the harmful component (Fig. 1). Ammonium nitrate has been reported to either have no effect on Fusarium diseases or to increase disease severity, similar to ammonium-N (Jones et al., 1989; Schneider, 1985). While this was generally true for Fusarium crown and root rot, testing a range of concentrations revealed that at low concentrations (10 to 100 mg·L–1 N), ammonium nitrate reduced disease similarly to nitrate-N (Figs. 1D, 2D). However, the negative influence of the NH4+ ion became apparent at concentrations above 125 mg·L–1 N (Figs. 1D, 2D). At higher concentrations, seedlings might have lacked sufficient available carbohydrates to convert the excess ammonium, which is toxic for tomato seedlings (Woltz et al., 1992), into nontoxic amino acids (Pate, 1973). Nitrates have long been recognized for their role in reducing seedling diseases caused by Rhizoctonia solani (Huber and Watson, 1974); however, contradictory results have been reported for Fusarium crown and root rot. Mihuta-Grimm et al. (1990) noted that nitrogen supplied as a 20N–20P–20K fertilizer had no effect on the growth of F. oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycopersici in rockwool compared to non-fertilized treatments. Jarvis and Thorpe (1980) found no effect of nitrogen form (with total N applied unspecified) on disease or yield when adequate lime was provided to counteract potential pH effects. In fact, the differential effect of nitrogen form on pH is a significant mechanism for suppressing many soilborne pathogens (Huber and Watson, 1974). In contrast, Woltz et al. (1992) reported differences between nitrate and ammonium-N (each at 225 mg·L–1).

Heremans (1996) developed a rapid method for screening tomato plant resistance to Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycopersici (Med. Fac. Landb. Toeg. Biol. Wetensch. Univ. Gent 61(2A):337–341). Huber and Watson (1974) examined nitrogen form and plant disease (Annu. Rev. Phytopathol. 12:139–165). Jarvis (1988, 1992) contributed significantly to managing diseases in greenhouse crops (Phytoprotection 69:49–64; APS Press, St. Paul, Minn.). Jarvis and Thorpe (1980, 1981) studied the effects of nitrate and ammonia nitrate on Fusarium severity and soil amendment with lettuce residues for disease control (Plant Dis. 64:309–310; Can. J. Plant Pathol. 3:159–162).

The exact way mineral nutrients influence disease is uncertain, but effects on pathogen activity and host susceptibility are likely involved. Fusarium oxysporum has a relatively high requirement for micronutrients (Jones et al., 1989). Concentrations of zinc, iron, manganese, and other metals above typical levels found in soil and nutrient solutions stimulate fungal growth and sporulation (Duffy and Défago, 1997; Jones et al., 1989). The profile of secondary metabolites produced by the pathogen, including phytotoxic compounds like fusaric acid, is also altered (Duffy and Défago, 1997; Egli, 1969). Nitrates inhibit both sporulation and spore germination, while ammonium has the opposite effect (Jones et al., 1989). Fertilization with nitrate-N decreases tomato sensitivity to fusaric acid, a phytotoxin produced in infected plants by Fusarium oxysporum (Barna et al., 1983). Zinc increases the susceptibility of tomatoes to fungal attack, partly because it raises the sugar level in plant tissues (Jarvis, 1992). Host susceptibility can also be altered by interactions between minerals, especially at elevated concentrations, impacting the availability of other nutrients. For instance, ammonium-N interferes with the uptake of nitrates and potassium, which in turn stimulates chloride uptake, leading to increased susceptibility of tomatoes to F. oxysporum f.sp. lycopersici (Jarvis, 1992). Disease suppression with minerals has also been attributed to the stimulation of indigenous populations of antagonistic microorganisms in the soil and rhizosphere (Elmer, 1995; Engelhard, 1989). While this is generally not relevant to hydroponics, recent work indicates that minerals can be utilized to enhance the beneficial activity of introduced biocontrol agents in soilless culture (Duffy and Défago, 1997).

The influence of various mineral nutrients on Fusarium crown and root rot was evaluated in a non-circulating hydroponics system. Pregerminated tomato seeds (cv. Bonnie Best), which were 2-3 days old and had sprouted primary roots measuring 2-4 mm in length on 0.85% water agar at 24 °C, were planted in rockwool cubes (3.5 cm in diameter and 4 cm deep; one seed per cube; Grodania A/S, Hedehusene, Denmark) placed in square plastic trays (5.5 cm deep). The rockwool was saturated with 800 mL of a dilute (1/4 strength) Knop nutrient solution containing the following concentrations (in mg·L–1): calcium nitrate (Ca(NO₃)₂·4H₂O) at 250; potassium phosphate (KH₂PO₄), potassium chloride (KCl), and magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄·7H₂O) at 62.52 each; and F2 e-EDDHA (ethylenediamine-di(o-hydroxyphenylacetic acid)).

The influence of nitrogen nutrition on the sensitivity of tomato plants to culture filtrates of Fusarium and to fusaric acid is discussed in "Physiology and Plant Pathology," volume 23, pages 257–263. Bochow et al. (1996) detail modes of action in biocontrolling fungal seedling and root rot diseases by Bacillus subtilis in the proceedings of the IOBC WPRS Bulletin, volume 19, pages 99–108. Duffy and Défago (1997) highlight that zinc amendment improves biocontrol of tomato crown and root rot by Pseudomonas fluorescens and represses the production of pathogen metabolites that inhibit bacterial antibiotic biosynthesis (Phytopathology 87:1250–1257).

Our results build on those of Woltz et al. (1992) and provide a foundation for developing a control strategy based on plant nutrition. Such an approach has been successfully applied to manage other Fusarium diseases (Jarvis, 1992; Jones et al., 1989). The effects of mineral nutrients on crown and root rot of tomatoes caused by F. oxysporum f.sp. radicis-lycospersici were similar to those reported for other formae speciales, reflecting the adaptability of control strategies for various Fusarium diseases. This further suggests a biological similarity of these pathogens and/or similar responses of diverse hosts to these fungi. However, fusarium crown and root rot is not the only issue threatening hydroponically grown tomatoes, and nontarget effects of certain mineral nutrients on other diseases must be considered. A prominent example is nitrate-N, which reduces crown and root rot but increases the severity of economically devastating diseases caused by Pythium and phytopathogenic bacteria (Stanghellini and Rasmussen, 1994). Integrating mineral nutrients with newly developed resistant cultivars, biocontrol agents, and/or fungicides used at reduced, non-phytotoxic concentrations may enhance the level and spectrum of disease control.

Crown rot severity increased with the lower CaCO₃ rate, the use of (NH₄)₂SO₄, and the addition of supplemental NaCl. Data on the fresh weight of seedlings, expressed as percentage values relative to non-inoculated controls, supported observations regarding the impact of Fusarium crown rot on tomato seedlings. Some Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. radicis-lycopersici (FORL) isolates may attack the roots aggressively, while others act as weak pathogens. This disease has been a notable issue in Florida (Jones et al., 1990) and is also recognized in greenhouse and field settings elsewhere (Brammall and McKeown, 1989; Jarvis and Thorpe, 1980; Vakalounakis, 1988).

Scientific investigations of anthracnose have focused on its epidemiology, the differences among the three causal Colletotrichum species, their infection processes, and pathogenicity. Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. Abstract: Fragaria ananassa (common name: strawberry) is a globally cultivated hybrid species belonging to the Rosaceae family. Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato (s.l.) is considered the second most economically important pathogen worldwide affecting strawberries. A collection of 148 Colletotrichum spp. isolates, including 67 C. acutatum s.l. isolates associated with the phytosanitary history of UK strawberry production, was used to characterize multilocus genetic variation of this pathogen in the UK, relative to additional reference isolates representing a worldwide sampling of the fungus diversity. Among the three species, C. nymphaeae and C. fioriniae appeared to be more aggressive compared to C. godetiae. This study highlights the genetic and pathogenic heterogeneity of the C. acutatum s.l. populations introduced into the UK linked to strawberry production.

Sutton (1992) noted that morphology alone does not provide sufficient information for precise identification, especially for species within the C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium complexes. Species with similar morphological characteristics may exhibit considerable variation at the physiological and pathogenic levels, making this recognition crucial for biosecurity, plant breeding, and integrated disease management. Taxonomy based solely on morphology is likely to result in ambiguity. Traditional methods of species identification have relied on morphological, cultural, and host-preference criteria. As stated by Sutton (1992), relying solely on morphology is insufficient for improving the systematics of species complexes like C. gloeosporioides.

Species concepts in Colletotrichum have evolved from the use of basic morphological data to a polyphasic approach that incorporates a significant molecular component. This evolution has made traditional classifications less practical, as holotypes and other types are not very useful since DNA cannot usually be extracted. It is recommended that future studies adopt a polyphasic approach before introducing new species of Colletotrichum or designating epitypes. query: What are the main host plants affected by Colletotrichum species, and what economic impact do they have?
retrieved_context: Filamentous fungi of the genus Colletotrichum and its teleomorph Glomerella are considered major plant pathogens worldwide. They cause significant economic damage to crops in tropical, subtropical, and temperate regions. Cereals, legumes, ornamentals, vegetables, and fruit trees may be seriously affected by these pathogens. Although many cultivated fruit crops are infected by Colletotrichum species, the most significant economic losses occur when the fruiting stage is attacked. Colletotrichum species cause typical disease symptoms known as anthracnose, characterized by sunken necrotic tissue where orange conidial masses are produced. Anthracnose diseases can appear in both developing and mature plant tissues.

The shift towards multi-gene phylogenetic analysis has significantly changed the classification and species concepts within the Colletotrichum genus (Cannon et al. 2012, Damm et al. 2012a, b, 2013, 2014, Weir et al. 2012). Many Colletotrichum species are classified as latent plant pathogens, endophytes, epiphytes, or saprobes, and may adopt a pathogenic lifestyle when host plants are stressed (Damm et al. 2009, Cannon et al. 2012). Systematic studies of nearly all recognized species have identified several complexes, revealing that some Colletotrichum species historically considered as causal agents of significant plant diseases are actually different species. For example, C. alienum is now recognized as a key species in Proteaceae cultivation (Liu et al. 2013), while C. acutatum s.lat. was found in Mediterranean countries causing diseases in various hosts, such as Fragaria × ananassa (Garrido et al. 2008), Arbutus unedo (Polizzi et al. 2011), and Olea europaea (Talhinhas et al. 2011). Given the economic losses in citrus orchards, understanding these species interactions is crucial.

The name C. fioriniae originates from C. acutatum var. fioriniae (Marcelino et al. 2008), which is derived from strains isolated during an epizootic infection of the exotic scale insect Fiorinia externa in the New England region. The implication of Colletotrichum species as entomopathogens may seem surprising; however, the insects involved are sap-suckers. C. fioriniae has been found widely as an endophyte (Marcelino et al. 2009) in both the host plant of the scale insect (Tsuga canadensis) and a diverse range of associated plants. This represents a case of mutualism between Colletotrichum and its host plants, with endophytic strains serving as natural protectants against insect herbivory. A similar occurrence was reported for a strain labeled C. gloeosporioides f. sp. ortheziidae (likely belonging to C. nymphaeae) parasitizing the economically significant citrus scale insect Orthezia praelonga in Brazil (Cesnik et al. 1996). Endophytic Colletotrichum strains have been shown to protect Theobroma cacao plants against Phytophthora pathogens (Arnold et al. 2003; Mejía et al. 2008; Rojas et al. 2010).

Agricultural losses due to Colletotrichum species particularly affect key staple crops in developing countries throughout the tropics and subtropics (Dean et al. 2012). These species can infect over 30 plant genera (Perfect et al. 1999, Farr et al. 2006, Damm et al. 2012a, b, Farr & Rossman 2017), causing anthracnose disease and postharvest decay in a wide range of tropical, subtropical, and temperate fruits, as well as grasses, vegetable crops, and ornamental plants (Bailey & Jeger 1992, Bernstein et al. 1995, Freeman & Shabi 1996, Crouch et al. 2009, Lima et al. 2011, Damm et al. 2012a, b, Anderson et al. 2013, Crous et al. 2016b, Guarnaccia et al. 2016, De Silva et al. 2017).

There exists high genome plasticity in Colletotrichum species, enabling them to adapt powerfully (Gan et al. 2021). Within the genus Colletotrichum, C. gloeosporioides s.l. is the most diversified complex, comprising as many as 57 species. This complex has been considered a heterogeneous species aggregate affecting over 700 plant species (O'Connell et al. 2012; Talhinhas and Baroncelli 2021; Farr and Rossman 2022). The most prevalent species in Chinese strawberry fields, C. siamense and C. fructicola, belong to C. gloeosporioides s.l. They are the two most frequently occurring Colletotrichum species globally, with significantly more records in Asia compared to other continents. Both species can affect more than 70 genera of hosts widely distributed across the phylogenetic tree of angiosperms. Compared to C. fructicola, C. siamense infects significantly more plants, including one gymnosperm. Notably, some Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries can also infect members of other kingdoms beyond plant hosts. For instance, the prevalent C. siamense in strawberry fields has been reported as a human pathogen, causing skin lesions in immunocompromised individuals (Werbel et al. 2019). C. truncatum has also been identified as an opportunistic human pathogen (Valenzuela-Lopez et al. 2018), while C. dematium has been reported to infect human tissues such as the cornea (Talhinhas and Baroncelli 2021). These associations between strawberry pathogens and humans highlight the importance of biosecurity in scientific research and agricultural practices.

Colletotrichum asianum and C. siamense have been reported as pathogens affecting a wide variety of hosts, including Coffea arabica, Carica papaya, and Mangifera indica. Our study demonstrated that a single host species could be attacked by several Colletotrichum species, a phenomenon previously noted by Phoulivong et al. C. fructicola was initially reported on coffee berries and also exhibits a broad host range, affecting species such as Arachis sp., Citrus bergamia, and M. indica, along with a wide geographical distribution. Similarly, C. tropicale has been documented on Annona muricata, Viola surinamensis, and M. indica in Brazil.

Records of plant hosts that are cross-infected or co-infected by multiple Colletotrichum species are not uncommon (Dean et al. 2012; Hirayama et al. 2018; da Silva et al. 2020). Indeed, the co-occurrence of C. fructicola and C. siamense has been identified in the same strawberry production field in Shanghai (Liu et al. 2021). The combined host range of these two Colletotrichum species was expanded to 152 genera, which includes one gymnosperm, 12 angiosperms (from six orders), 38 monocots (from 10 orders), and 101 dicots (from 22 orders). Among the combined hosts of C. fructicola and C. siamense, the top four orders are Fabales, Sapindales, Rosales, and Asparagales, each containing 12, 12, 11, and 11 genera, respectively.

This article emphasizes that certain populations of Colletotrichum appear to be host-specific, exemplified by C. gloeosporioides from almond in Israel. However, in other geographic regions, the same host may be affected by additional species, as recently demonstrated with C. acutatum causing almond anthracnose in California. The presence of intermediate forms has introduced ambiguity into species identification. The validity of these mycotaxons as “mycological (formerly botanical) species” is significant from a phytopathological perspective but lies beyond the scope of this article.

Various studies highlight the significance of Colletotrichum species in agriculture. Crouch et al. (2009) discussed anthracnose disease caused by the novel species Colletotrichum navitas, while Damm et al. (2013) addressed the Colletotrichum orbiculare species complex, which affects field crops and weeds. Other works by Damm et al. (2012) explored the Colletotrichum acutatum and Colletotrichum boninense species complexes.

Host Range and Specificity Some Colletotrichum species exhibit extensive host ranges, while others are more specific. Certain strains, such as C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum, infect a broad range of hosts, whereas others, like C. dematium, may have more restricted host interactions. These characteristics are vital for the development of commercial mycoherbicides aimed at controlling specific weeds like northern jointvetch.

Quiescent infections occurring before harvest develop as the fruit ripens, leading to ripe rot of blueberry and bitter rot of apple after harvest. Postharvest symptoms can also emerge with anthracnose diseases affecting peaches, almonds, and other stone fruits. Additionally, many tropical fruits like avocado, mango, papaya, and guava can suffer from postharvest decay due to quiescent infections established in the field.

Papaya is a climacteric fleshy fruit typically harvested at the pre-climacteric stage, meaning that ripening begins after harvest, resulting in a relatively short shelf life. During this period, several fruit rot pathogens, including Colletotrichum spp., can cause damage. Although papaya anthracnose symptoms can occur in both fruits and leaves, Colletotrichum infections are usually more severe in fruits. Refrigerated papayas are particularly susceptible to disease; therefore, fruits intended for export may develop anthracnose symptoms as they ripen.

C. acutatum manifests symptoms on flowers, leaves, petioles, and roots, but it is most significant as a fruit rot pathogen in strawberries. It also affects citrus, apples, mangoes, papayas, and avocados, alongside C. gloeosporioides. In citrus, C. gloeosporioides is a common saprophyte and can cause postharvest anthracnose due to preharvest quiescent infections. Although C. acutatum does not cause postharvest anthracnose in citrus, it leads to specific diseases like postbloom fruit drop and key lime anthracnose. On apples, C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum both contribute to bitter rot, but C. acutatum is not known to infect apple leaves.

Anthracnose can occur in avocados wherever they are grown, particularly during the wet season and in areas with high rainfall. Major infections typically affect the fruit, although leaves and stems can also be impacted. The dark lesions caused by anthracnose pathogens can rapidly expand on the fruit's surface and infect the pulp, leading to rot [84].

Two distinct types of diseases occur: those affecting developing fruit in the field (preharvest) and those damaging mature fruit during storage (postharvest). The ability to cause latent or quiescent infections has categorized Colletotrichum among the most important postharvest pathogens. Species of the pathogen predominantly appear on aboveground plant tissues; however, belowground organs, such as roots and tubers, may also be affected.

Anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum was less severe on fruit from greenhouse-grown plants receiving drench or foliar applications of calcium sulfate than on fruit from plants receiving water, calcium chloride, or calcium nitrate treatments. Fruit from plants receiving foliar applications of CaCl₂ developed less fruit rot than that from plants receiving soil applications of CaCl₂ (Smith and Gupton, 1993). The primary means to reduce the buildup of anthracnose fruit rot in the field is to harvest fruit frequently and remove all rotten fruit. Following severe infections early in the fruiting season, all infected fruit should be stripped from the plants and removed from the field. Infected areas of a field should be harvested last in the day, or workers should wash up and change to clean clothes when entering uninfected areas of the field after harvesting areas with fruit rot present.

In terms of virulence, anthracnose symptoms can vary among different fruits based on factors such as the variety of the fruit, inoculum concentration, humidity, and temperature. Furthermore, pathogenic variation among Colletotrichum species infecting fruit crops has been documented. The diverse species of Colletotrichum that cause anthracnose in fruit crops also pose quarantine concerns. Fruits such as banana, papaya, mango, dragon fruit, guava, and avocado are exported and imported worldwide, and latent infections are a key part of the disease cycle for anthracnose pathogens. This raises the possibility of these pathogens being distributed to new areas or regions.

On certain fruits, such as apple and blueberry (Vaccinium spp.), members of the C. acutatum species complex cause both pre-harvest and post-harvest diseases (Milholland, 1995; Jones et al., 1996; Shi et al., 1996). On these plants, asymptomatic, quiescent infections occur on unripe fruit, developing into necrotic lesions as the fruit ripens (Alkan et al., 2015). There are many other examples of post-harvest decay in fruits like peaches (Prunus persica), almonds (Prunus dulcis), avocado (Persea americana), mango (Mangifera indica), papaya (Carica papaya), and guava (Psidium guajava) that stem from quiescent infections that began in the field (Agostini et al., 1992; Freeman and Shabi, 1996; Smith, 1998; Afanador-Kafuri et al., 2003).

Molecular tools have effectively distinguished Colletotrichum species, clearly separating C. acutatum from C. gloeosporioides and identifying genetically distinct subgroups within C. acutatum. Nonetheless, the disease cycles of C. acutatum in many host-pathogen systems remain poorly understood, even in economically important crops. This pathogen can reproduce on various tissue types across different hosts and can exist as a necrotroph, biotroph, endophyte, or epiphyte, depending on the plant species and tissue involved. The tissues affected are very specific for each host combination, and the pathogen develops a highly specialized relationship at the cellular level that is evident in the disease cycle for each host. Further investigation is needed into the biotrophic and epiphytic phases of the pathogen and the means by which C. acutatum reproduces in the absence of pathogenesis. The tissue specificity and life cycles of C. acutatum are likely under genetic control, and it may be possible to induce mutants that are no longer pathogenic to certain hosts or tissues, thereby elucidating the genetic basis for tissue or host specificity, as seen in other Colletotrichum species.

Numerous studies have reported subgroups within the C. acutatum species complex. A multilocus molecular phylogenetic analysis (ITS, ACT, TUB2, CHS-1, GAPDH, HIS3) involving 331 strains previously identified as C. acutatum and related taxa—spanning various hosts across diverse geographic regions—confirmed the previously recognized molecular groups and identified several novel taxa. Thirty-one species are accepted, of which 21 have not been previously recognized. Colletotrichum orchidophilum clusters basal to the C. acutatum species complex. This complex exhibits high phenotypic diversity, with some species showing preferences for specific hosts or geographic regions, while others are plurivorous and found in multiple areas. In this study, only C. salicis and C. rhombiforme formed sexual morphs in culture; however, sexual morphs have been documented from other taxa, particularly in laboratory crosses, with evidence of hybridization between different species. A new species, C. pseudoacutatum, was also described, resembling C. acutatum but not belonging to its species complex.

Numerous light and electron microscopic studies describing plant interactions with Colletotrichum species have been published; however, we have not found studies on the ultrastructure of the C. acutatum and C. fragariae systems in strawberries. A detailed consideration of biotrophy, necrotrophy, and hemibiotrophy is essential for understanding the invasion mechanisms of C. acutatum and C. fragariae. Biotrophy is characterized by the fungus maintaining host cells alive while extracting nutrients from them (9, 16). Necrotrophy involves the fungus killing living host cells before entering their lumina (9, 12, 16, 28). Hemibiotrophy is a phase where the fungus initially engages in a biotrophic phase before transitioning to a necrotrophic phase (9). The initial penetration and invasion processes of a plant host by a fungal pathogen in the context of strawberry anthracnose are crucial for understanding these dynamics.

Colletotrichum acutatum has been regarded as a pathogen of countless host plant species and is thought to occur everywhere. Sreenivasaprasad & Talhinhas (2005) discovered that C. acutatum group A5, accepted here as C. acutatum s. str., occurs only on certain hosts, primarily in the southern hemisphere. This study confirms that C. acutatum s. str. does indeed have multiple hosts, but the known host spectrum is much smaller than previously accepted.

Few investigations into cross-pathogenicity and the host range of C. acutatum isolates in nature have been conducted. If this pathogen truly has a broad host range and can move freely between hosts, it is intriguing that it has formed unique relationships with each plant species. Many researchers face limitations due to narrow crop responsibilities, inadequate facilities for handling temperate or tropical crops, or restrictions imposed by biosecurity regulations, which have hindered studies of host ranges using large numbers of isolates. With innovation and cooperative efforts, it may be possible to conduct some of these studies, ultimately enhancing our understanding of pathogen movement and host interactions.

The objective of this study was to investigate the inheritance of high and intermediate plant resistance to C. acutatum isolates from pathogenicity group 2 to enhance understanding of anthracnose resistance. An 8 × 8 factorial design was employed, focusing on analyzing the disease's intermediate resistance, indicating that minor genes may also contribute to resistance in certain cultivars, such as Belrubi. The intermediate level of resistance was found to be quantitative and governed by minor genes. Analyzing 26 genotypes and cultivars from Fragaria spp. revealed that the dominant gene is not rare in the germplasm of F. × ananassa, and anthracnose resistance is also present in other Fragaria species. These findings hold significant implications for breeding efforts aimed at enhancing anthracnose resistance.

Colletotrichum acutatum was identified by Simmonds (1965) and validated by the same author in 1968. Although the C. acutatum species complex is regarded as polyphagous, the lupin anthracnose pathogen forms a well-defined, homogeneous, and host-specific group, unlike other heterogeneous and polyphagous groups (Talhinhas et al., 2016). A similar situation applies to safflower (Carthamus tinctorius), where only strains of C. chrysanthemi were pathogenic to safflower. Strains genetically close but belonging to different species were not pathogenic on the same host (Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005; Baroncelli et al., 2015a). While approximately 7% of the scientific literature on Colletotrichum from 1991 to 2000 addressed C. acutatum, this proportion rose to 18% in the following decade, depicting C. acutatum as a “popular” entity (based on an ISI Web of Science search of 1839 publications during 1991–2010 containing “Colletotrichum” in the title). Other members of the species complex with a strong relationship to specific hosts include C. phormii, pathogenic to Phormium spp., and C. tamarilloi, the causal agent of tamarillo (Solanum betaceum) anthracnose (Baroncelli, 2012; Damm et al., 2012).

Considering the frequency with which strains from the C. acutatum species complex are encountered and their pathogenicity to a wide range of crop plants, it would be surprising if earlier names for C. acutatum did not exist. Walker et al. (1991) found that C. xanthii (Halsted 1893) was synonymous with C. acutatum based on morphological criteria, but no authentic sequences are available, and it is currently unclear which clade this species fits into. At that time, there was no interest among Colletotrichum researchers to replace the name C. acutatum, and now the name is so widely used that a change would likely not gain recognition. Other older taxa have been recognized as belonging to the C. acutatum complex, but as close relatives rather than formal synonyms. Colletotrichum lupini was found to be an independent taxon within the C. acutatum complex by Nirenberg et al. Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum species is one of the most destructive diseases affecting strawberry production worldwide. Fungi of the genus Colletotrichum, which are ancient and co-evolved with flowering plants, rank eighth among the ten most economically important fungal pathogens and have diversified to adapt to various hosts. Since its first report in the United States in 1931, strawberry anthracnose has spread globally, resulting in devastating economic, social, and ecological consequences.
