Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.

The difficulty in controlling anthracnose crown rot arises from the fact that Colletotrichum spp. can kill strawberry plants after aggressively invading crown tissue, with a long latent period during which no symptoms are visible. Additionally, there are no long-term effective fungicides available, and the diverse origins of the causal agents are unpredictable (Peres et al., 2017; Forcelini and Peres, 2018; Hirayama et al., 2018). Furthermore, Colletotrichum spp. can be dispersed from asymptomatic plants over long distances, while relevant quarantine measures for strawberry trade are lacking in China. Recognizing the causal agents is a prerequisite for disease control. Initially, identification largely depended on morphological observation and virulence tests. Repeated in vitro subculturing of microbes can alter both their morphology and virulence. The fact that morphological characteristics can vary based on host choice or environmental conditions poses a significant concern for fungal identification. Strawberry anthracnose was first reported nearly a century ago (Brooks, 1931). Through PCR and DNA sequencing techniques, researchers have clarified the genetic distinctions among Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, categorizing pathogens of worldwide origin into C. acutatum, C. fragariae, and C. gloeosporioides (Martínez-Culebras et al., 2000, 2003). However, ambiguously annotated data for Colletotrichum species frequently appear in GenBank, leading to confusion (Nilsson et al., 2006; Hyde et al., 2009). The emergence of multi-locus phylogeny has significantly aided in the identification of fungal species. Many pathologists and biologists have greatly expanded knowledge of Colletotrichum systematics (Cannon et al., 2012; Damm et al., 2012a, b; Weir et al., 2012), providing a solid foundation for future research. A landmark study corrected many synonymous names and offered a valuable reference for understanding Colletotrichum pathogens (Hyde et al., 2014). The delineation of Colletotrichum species and the description of new species continue to progress with the advent of novel technologies such as whole genome sequencing (Jayawardena et al., 2020, 2021; Bhunjun et al., 2021; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021).

To address this challenge, it is urgent to investigate the temperature adaptation of Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries, particularly the prevalent ones like C. siamense and C. fructicola, focusing on their life cycles and pathogenesis. For effective control of anthracnose crown rot, developing disease-resistant strawberry varieties is essential. Resistance to crown anthracnose rot, combined with enhanced tolerance to high temperatures, should be a primary objective for strawberry breeders. Under global warming, significant latitudinal range shifts of plant pathogens have been observed, indicating that migration, rather than in situ adaptation to new climates, is the dominant response of pathogen populations to changing climates. Frequent host jumps and transitions facilitate the emergence of new fungal pathogens (Bebber et al. 2013; Chaloner et al. 2020). The evolution and flexibility of both temperature responses and host ranges among destructive Colletotrichum spp. contribute to their spread, invasion, and threat to strawberry production. Various factors, including humidity, temperature, fruit condition, and inoculum concentration, can influence Colletotrichum infection.

Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum spp. is a significant threat to strawberry production, particularly in warm and humid climates. Rain-splashed conidia of Colletotrichum spp. serve as the primary inoculum that initiates epidemics of strawberry anthracnose disease. After landing on the plant surface, the conidia germinate, form appressoria, and then penetrate the epidermal cells. Colletotrichum spp. can infect various strawberry tissues, resulting in black or irregular spots on leaves, sunken black spots or necrotic lesions on petioles, stolons, and fruits, as well as wilting of the entire plant due to crown rot. Under high humidity, concentric rings of acervuli with orange conidial masses can be observed on necrotic tissues. In Florida, USA, anthracnose can lead to the death of up to 80% of seedlings in nurseries and yield losses exceeding 50% in fields. In Taiwan, strawberry seedlings are propagated from March to September, during which high temperatures, humidity, and heavy rainfall are prevalent.

The time from infection of strawberries by Colletotrichum spp. to first sporulation (the latent period) is an important factor in the speed at which anthracnose may spread within a field. The latent period depends on temperature and ranges from 2–3 days at 25 °C to 6–17 days at 5 °C (King et al., 1997). At 5 and 10 °C, the latent period was shorter for C. acutatum than for C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae; however, at higher temperatures, the latent period for all species was similar. Appressoria and secondary conidia produced by C. acutatum on symptomless foliage may be a significant source of inoculum for fruit infections (Leandro et al., 2001) and may also contribute to the availability of inoculum throughout the growing season (Leandro et al., 2003a). Conidial germination, appressorial production, and secondary conidiation are all favored by longer periods of wetness than the 4 hours required for secondary conidia to form. Colletotrichum acutatum survived up to 8 weeks on leaves in greenhouse studies (Leandro et al., 2003a) and up to 5 weeks on fabric (Norman and Strandberg, 1997). More conidia formed on leaves when exposed to flower extracts than when exposed to leaf extracts or water (Leandro et al., 2003b), suggesting that C. acutatum inoculum levels on strawberry foliage may increase during flowering. Rain splash is the primary means by which Colletotrichum spp. conidia are spread from plant to plant in the field. Madden and Boudreau (1997) found that the incidence of anthracnose fruit rot generally declined as plant density increased, concluding that higher plant density reduced the amount of rain that penetrated the plant canopy, thus reducing splash. Most fruit infections occurred within a 25-cm radius of the inoculum source, which is an infected fruit (Madden and Wilson, 1997). Ntahimpera et al. (1999) studied the splash dispersal of conidia from the three Colletotrichum spp. and found that C. fragariae conidia dispersed over the shortest distance, while those of C. acutatum dispersed over the longest distance. This was likely due to the greater number of spores produced on infected fruit by C. acutatum. Conidia of Colletotrichum acutatum may survive in soil and plant debris under dry conditions for up to 12 months, but conidia and sclerotia die rapidly under moist conditions, specifically in soil moisture levels exceeding 12% (Norman and Strandberg, 1997).

Colletotrichum is an ancient fungus that has co-evolved with flowering plants. Plant microfossils of Protocolletotrichum preserved on angiosperm leaf cuticles suggest that the diverse pathogenic strategies of Colletotrichum spp. have been established since the Late Cretaceous period (Kar et al., 2004). Different complexes within the genus may have diverged between 4.8 and 32.2 million years ago (MYA) (Bhunjun et al., 2021). The emergence of agricultural cultivation and the intensive disturbance of natural environments have further driven the diversification of Colletotrichum species. These fungi have adapted to thousands of hosts and can be found as endophytes, pathogens, and saprobes (Freeman et al., 1998; Dean et al., 2012; Hirayama et al., 2018; da Silva et al., 2020; Jayawardena et al., 2020). Currently, a total of 257 Colletotrichum species grouped into 15 complexes and 13 additional singletons have been accepted in this genus.

The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).

The diverse species of Colletotrichum that cause anthracnose in fruit crops also pose quarantine concerns. Abstract: In tropical fruit crops, anthracnose is primarily caused by species of the fungal genus Colletotrichum. These phytopathogens can infect various parts of the fruit crops; however, infections occurring during postharvest or ripening stages lead to significant economic losses. The disease manifests as black to dark brown sunken lesions on the fruit surface, which diminishes fruit quality and marketability. Common tropical fruit crops susceptible to anthracnose include mango, papaya, banana, avocado, guava, and dragon fruit, all of which are economically important in many developing countries. It is essential to note that newly identified Colletotrichum species associated with fruit anthracnose can infect multiple hosts, though some species may exhibit host specificity. Utilizing multiple markers, many phylogenetic species of Colletotrichum have been recognized as anthracnose-causing pathogens. Given that effective disease management strategies depend on a comprehensive understanding of the causative agents, up-to-date information regarding Colletotrichum species and the risks posed by newly identified species in tropical fruit plantations and harvested fruits is crucial. Furthermore, these newly recorded species may be significant for biosecurity and should be classified as quarantine pathogens, particularly as tropical fruits are traded globally.

query: How do different Colletotrichum species contribute to the overall impact of anthracnose diseases?
retrieved_context: Three species have been documented as causal agents of strawberry anthracnose: Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, C. fragariae, and C. acutatum (Denoyes-Rothan et al. 2003). The anthracnose disease caused by Colletotrichum spp. impacts a wide variety of woody and herbaceous plants, particularly tropical and subtropical crops and fruit trees (Cannon et al. 2012; Freeman et al. 1998; Hyde et al. 2009; Sutton 1992; Wikee et al. 2011). The genus has recently been recognized as the world's eighth most important group of plant-pathogenic fungi due to its scientific and economic significance (Dean et al. 2012). However, the identification of Colletotrichum spp. has historically been challenging. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have often failed to accurately delineate species (Hyde et al. 2009). Ko Ko et al. (2011) emphasized the need to resurvey plant pathogens like Colletotrichum spp. using molecular methods, as previous morphological and internal transcribed spacer data are likely to be incorrect. Understanding of Colletotrichum spp. has significantly advanced through these molecular approaches.

Colletotrichum species are primarily recognized as the causal agents of anthracnose, which occurs on various plant parts, including leaves, stems, flowers, and fruits. The disease cycles of anthracnose on different hosts exhibit similar components (Peres et al., 2005; De Silva et al., 2017); they are typically polycyclic, with splash-borne asexual spores (conidia) initiating and spreading epidemics. Other Colletotrichum-related diseases include crown rot in strawberries and black dot disease on the roots of tomatoes and potatoes (Dillard and Cobb, 1997; Dillard and Cobb, 1998; Waller et al., 2002). Additionally, Colletotrichum species can cause post-harvest diseases, particularly in avocado, almond, and citrus fruits (Prusky, 1996; Ismail and Zhang, 2004; Prusky et al., 2013). In these cases, the pathogens form infection structures (appressoria) on the host but remain dormant within the fruit until after harvest, during which symptoms may emerge (Ismail and Zhang, 2004; Prusky et al., 2013). Several studies have indicated that species within a clade exhibit similar colonization and infection behaviors, with the establishment of quiescence being host- and tissue-specific (Sanders and Korsten, 2003; Damm et al., 2012; Weir et al., 2012; Prusky et al., 2013; Jayawardena et al., 2016; Zakaria, 2021). Furthermore, species within clades have comparable temperature requirements for mycelial growth, conidial germination, infection, and spore production (Salotti et al., 2022). For example, species such as C. gloeosporioides, C. fragariae, C. gossypii, and C. musaebelonging to the gloeosporioides clade show optimum temperatures for mycelial growth, sporulation, conidial germination, and infection between 25 and 32°C (Salotti et al., 2022).

Many species belonging to the genus Colletotrichum are associated with plant diseases, commonly referred to as anthracnose. Colletotrichum spp. can affect a wide range of hosts, and these pathogens are characterized by global distribution. Virtually every cultivated botanical family is susceptible to one or more species of Colletotrichum, making it one of the most studied plant pathogenic fungi (Prusky et al., 2000; Latunde-Dada, 2001; Dean et al., 2012). Common hosts include many dicotyledonous plants such as strawberry, apple, citrus, and stone fruits, as well as major cereals such as maize and sorghum. Members of this genus can cause crop losses of up to 100% in many staple foods (Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 2000; Talhinhas et al., 2005; Cannon et al., 2012).

Anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum spp., is a serious disease affecting strawberries. The etiology of anthracnose in strawberries is complex, with several Colletotrichum species identified as causal agents. In this study, multilocus phylogenetic analysis (utilizing genes such as actin, β-tubulin, calmodulin, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and chitin synthase) revealed that 100 isolates of Colletotrichum associated with anthracnose of strawberry in central China belong to five species. Specifically, 97 isolates were identified as belonging to the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex, with the distribution as follows: C. murrayae (81%), C. gloeosporioides (8%), C. fructicola (4%), and C. aenigma (4%). Additionally, three isolates from the C. acutatum complex were identified as C. nymphaeae.

A significant effort has been dedicated to identifying which species of Colletotrichum are involved in various anthracnose-type diseases of plants and developing tools for their identification and differentiation. Multiple hosts can be affected by a single species, while multiple species can impact a single host. Simmonds was the first to describe C. acutatum as a new species, distinct from others.

However, clade-based calibration can also provide advantages. Anthracnose diseases are often attributed to several Colletotrichum species within the same clade, depending on the region. For example, the main causal agents of olive anthracnose are found in the acutatum clade, with C. godetiae being dominant in Spain, Italy, Greece, and Tunisia; C. nymphaeae prevalent in Portugal; and C. oriniae predominant in California (Moral et al., 2021). Furthermore, accurate identification of Colletotrichum species necessitates molecular analysis of multiple DNA regions (Damm et al., 2009; Damm et al., 2012; Weir et al., 2012; Damm et al., 2013; Damm et al., 2014). Since species within the same clade often exhibit similar environmental requirements (Salotti et al., 2022), a clade-based calibration may help address knowledge gaps regarding individual Colletotrichum species, facilitate practical model usage when species identification is challenging due to capacity or economic limitations, and enable predictions across a diverse range of hosts and climatic conditions.

In this research, we developed a general, weather-driven, mechanistic model for predicting anthracnose diseases caused by Colletotrichum spp. on the aerial parts of different host plants in the field. Previous models for anthracnose diseases were species- and crop-specific and considered only one component of the pathogen life cycle, mainly conidial infection (Dodd et al., 1991; Park et al., 1992; Monroe et al., 1997; Moral et al., 2012; Singh, 2020). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time that such a model has been developed, calibrated for different clades and host plants, and evaluated to make predictions of anthracnose patterns across multiple crops.

Accurate identification of species is essential for effective management of anthracnose disease. Currently, three Colletotrichum species—C. acutatum, C. boninense, and C. gloeosporioides—have been reported to cause anthracnose in mango. However, the C. gloeosporioides species complex, which consists of ubiquitous fungal pathogens in tropical and subtropical regions, has not been documented in Thailand. The host association and morphological characteristics traditionally used to identify Colletotrichum species are insufficient for distinguishing these pathogens at the species level due to the limited number of morphological traits and the lack of host specificity.

Based on field trials in Florida (Mertely et al., 2009), the recommendation for anthracnose control involves weekly applications of a broad-spectrum protectant fungicide (captan) at the lowest label rate early in the season when conditions are less favorable for anthracnose development. Later, when anthracnose-infected flowers and fruit may be present, it is recommended to increase the rate of the protectant fungicide to the highest label rate. Warm, rainy weather in early spring often leads to epidemics, during which additional fungicides may be necessary. Growers are encouraged to scout their fields regularly for anthracnose symptoms, such as blighted flowers or black spots on green fruit. If symptoms are detected, the application of a strobilurin fungicide (such as Abound or Cabrio) in conjunction with the protectant fungicide is recommended. During the main bloom period, in late January and early February, fungicides containing two active ingredients (one for anthracnose control and one for Botrytis fruit rot control), such as CaptEvate, Pristine, or Switch, are advised. Tank mixes or higher rates of protectant fungicides should be maintained until the end of the harvest season or until dry weather effectively suppresses the disease.

ABSTRACT: Strawberry anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum fragariae, is a serious problem in the southeastern United States, resulting in significant losses in strawberry nurseries. Control measures using fungicides are crucial, particularly with recommended applications of captafol, benomyl, captan, and maneb.

Control of Colletotrichum acutatum is highly dependent on frequent applications of both multi-site and single-site fungicides (Mertely et al. 2017a, b). Multi-site fungicides, such as captan, provide satisfactory control of C. acutatum, but they lack a curative effect, necessitating weekly applications throughout the season (Mertely et al. 2017b). Due to its high performance (Nuin et al. 2006; Golubchik et al. 2007; Dessimoz and Gil 2010; Letsch et al. 2010; Sahraeian and Yoon 2011; Sievers et al. 2011), MAFFT has gained popularity in recent years. Following the review of the previous version (version 6) by Katoh and Toh (2008b), we have continuously enhanced its accuracy, speed, and utility in practical applications. These improvements and techniques have been documented in various papers (Katoh et al. 2009; Katoh and Toh 2010; Katoh and Frith 2012; Katoh and Standley 2013).

All options in MAFFT assume that the input sequences are homologous, meaning they are derived from a common ancestor during evolution. Consequently, all characters in the input data are aligned. The software does not account for genomic rearrangements or domain shuffling, ensuring that the order of characters in each sequence is preserved, although sequences can be reordered based on similarity. Most MAFFT options presume that nearly all pairs in the input sequences can be aligned, either locally or globally, which introduces a tradeoff between accuracy and speed. For instance, the PartTree option (Katoh and Toh 2007) is a quick but less precise method, while L-INS-i and G-INS-i are slower yet more accurate. For instance, a repetitive nuclear DNA element (GcpR1), originally identified in the bean anthracnose pathogen C. lindemuthianum, was successfully used to differentiate among 10 species of Colletotrichum, producing unique polymorphic patterns for each species. When GcpR1 was employed to compare C. gloeosporioides isolates from almond and avocado in Israel, the band patterns of the almond isolates were uniform and distinct from those of the avocado isolates. Additionally, polymorphic fragments were observed within the avocado isolates, correlating with the morphological and VCG heterogeneity of this population.

HaeIII RFLPs of A+T-rich DNA were successfully used to characterize Colletotrichum isolates from 10 species, with each representative revealing unique restriction patterns. The results of this approach were similar to those obtained using the GcpR1 repetitive element, where C. gloeosporioides isolates from almond exhibited unique band patterns, in contrast to the polymorphic fragments observed for avocado isolates. This method also facilitated the grouping of C. acutatum isolates from apple and peach, as well as differentiation among C. gloeosporioides isolates from almond, apple, avocado, and mango.

To categorize strains into different groups, other studies have utilized random amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD) polymorphisms, internal transcribed spacer-restriction fragment length polymorphisms (ITS-RFLP), and classifications based on ITS sequences (Gautam, 2014; Smith, 2008). While RAPD and ITS-RFLP polymorphisms indicate genetic variability among isolates, specific polymorphisms have not yet been linked to particular species. Moreover, classifying strains using a single marker sequence has proven insufficient for distinguishing between different species within the C. gloeosporioides species complex (Weir et al., 2012).

However, since this study only analyzed a single region and did not use multiple genes, the results may not be entirely accurate. Indeed, multigene phylogenetic analyses, combined with morphological characteristics, have been used to identify many important pathogens (Cai et al. 2009; Damm et al. 2012; Weir et al. 2012). The classification and delimitation of Colletotrichum species have been debated (Weir et al. 2012). Many Colletotrichum isolates have been successfully identified based on multigene phylogenies and morphological characteristics, indicating that this method is mature and can accurately identify pathogens (Damm et al. 2012). However, morphological characteristics and multigene phylogenies have not yet been used to identify the Colletotrichum species associated with strawberry anthracnose in China or to determine the distributions of these species.

In summary, rDNA analysis is a reliable method for taxonomic species identification, while the use of GcpR1 and other repetitive DNA elements, A+T-rich DNA RFLPs, and ap-PCR are valuable methods for assessing subpopulation diversity within species.

A subset of isolates was also used to assess aggressiveness in causing disease on strawberry plants and fruits. Isolates belonging to C. nymphaeae, C. godetiae, and C. fioriniae, representative of the UK anthracnose pathogen populations, showed variation in their aggressiveness. Among the three species, C. nymphaeae and C. fioriniae appeared to be more aggressive compared to C. godetiae. In the southeastern United States, anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot can be particularly severe in strawberry production fields, especially during wet harvest seasons, which can lead to total crop loss. Fungicides are used to control anthracnose diseases; however, several have become ineffective due to the development of fungicide-resistant strains of the pathogens. Field observations in Florida indicated that growing strawberry plants in soils with low N levels reduced the severity of anthracnose, although this also severely limited fruit production. Both the form of nitrogen and calcium levels influence disease severity. For instance, calcium has been employed to manage soil-borne diseases caused by Pythium spp. on various crops, while nitrate forms of N have been shown to suppress Fusarium wilt in tomatoes, whereas ammonium forms increase disease severity.

As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.

Past failures of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may have stemmed from the development of resistance in the Colletotrichum population. In the early 1970s, benomyl effectively reduced anthracnose crown rot incidence (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was widely used by strawberry growers for years. However, anthracnose pathogens developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering benomyl ineffective. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). Current fungicide labels address pathogen resistance by restricting the number of consecutive and total applications of a product per season. For instance, the fungicides Abound (azoxystrobin, Syngenta, Greensboro, NC), Cabrio (pyraclostrobin, BASF, Research Triangle Park, NC), and Pristine (pyraclostrobin and boscalid, BASF) are limited to four or five applications per season, with no more than two consecutive applications before alternating with a fungicide that has a different mode of action. Natural products have also been evaluated as alternative fungicides, offering different modes of action, lower toxicity, and increased efficacy (Abril et al., 2008).

Due to restrictions associated with fungicide applications, their adverse environmental effects, and the potential development of resistance among fungal strains, the use of resistant cultivars is considered the most effective method for managing this disease. This study evaluated the reactions of 25 commercial strawberry cultivars against the fungus Colletotrichum nymphaeae, which causes AFR, using fruit, leaf, and crown-based assays. Results indicated that the cultivars exhibited varying reactions to the disease, depending on the inoculation of their leaves, fruits, and crowns with C. nymphaeae PET1 under in vivo and greenhouse conditions. The fruit-based assay was determined to be a better indicator of susceptibility to AFR due to the nature of the disease. Overall, 'Blakemore' and 'Kurdistan' cultivars showed significantly higher resistance compared to others, except for 'Aliso', 'Mrak', 'Diamant', 'Yallova', 'New Kurdistan', 'Mac Donance', and 'Ten Beauty'. Conversely, the 'Gaviota' cultivar was found to be significantly the most susceptible, aside from 'Camarosa'. The commonly grown commercial cultivars in Iran, including 'Camarosa', 'Paros', 'Pajaro', and 'Queen Eliza', were categorized as susceptible to highly susceptible in this study. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study evaluating the reaction of commercial strawberry cultivars to C. nymphaeae causing strawberry AFR.

Nonetheless, the disease cycles of C. acutatum in many host-pathogen systems remain poorly understood, even in economically important crops. This pathogen can reproduce on various tissue types across different hosts and can exist as a necrotroph, biotroph, endophyte, or epiphyte, depending on the plant species and tissue involved. The tissues affected are very specific for each host combination, and the pathogen develops a highly specialized relationship at the cellular level that is evident in the disease cycle for each host. Further investigation is needed into the biotrophic and epiphytic phases of the pathogen and the means by which C. acutatum reproduces in the absence of pathogenesis. The tissue specificity and life cycles of C. acutatum are likely under genetic control, and it may be possible to induce mutants that are no longer pathogenic to certain hosts or tissues, thereby elucidating the genetic basis for tissue or host specificity, as seen in other Colletotrichum species.

Colletotrichum gloeosporioides sensu lato is a significant pathogen responsible for mango anthracnose globally. In some cases, C. acutatum sensu lato has also been linked to the disease. Phylogenetic analyses based on internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequences reveal that C. gloeosporioides comprises diverse groups or sub-populations, suggesting that other Colletotrichum species may also be associated with mango anthracnose. Studies indicate that Colletotrichum isolates from mango can consist of pathogenically and genetically distinct populations of C. gloeosporioides. According to Ploetz (1999), the C. gloeosporioides population on mango has a restricted host range and is highly virulent solely on mango. Following the phylogenetic analyses of the Colletotrichum genus by Phoulivong et al. (2012) and Weir et al. (2012), several species within the C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum complexes, including C. gloeosporioides, have been associated with mango anthracnose.

Previously, anthracnose pathogens were often identified as Colletotrichum gloeosporioides or C. acutatum, primarily due to the identification procedures that typically did not utilize multiple markers, often analyzing only the Internal Transcribed Spacer (ITS) region. Consequently, the data obtained may not accurately reflect the true causal pathogens. It is now acknowledged that C. gloeosporioides is not the most common anthracnose pathogen affecting tropical fruit crops, as previously believed. Various Colletotrichum species are known to cause anthracnose in tropical fruit crops, presenting significant limitations in the production and marketing of these commodities.

Colletotrichum species causing anthracnose in chili have previously been identified as C. acutatum (characterized by straight conidia with acute ends), C. gloeosporioides (straight conidia with obtuse ends), and C. truncatum (falcate conidia) (Than et al. 2008; Mongkolporn et al. 2010). However, recent multigene phylogenetic analyses have revealed that C. acutatum is a species complex (the acutatum complex) consisting of 34 closely related species (Marin-Felix et al. 2017), with seven species identified as responsible for anthracnose in chili (Mongkolporn and Taylor 2018). Similarly, C. gloeosporioides has been found to be a complex of 38 closely related species (Marin-Felix et al. 2017), with nine species identified as pathogens of chili (Mongkolporn and Taylor 2018). Morphological traits are insufficient to differentiate many species with straight conidia, particularly those in the acutatum and gloeosporioides complexes affecting chili. Thus, multigene phylogenetic analyses are essential for accurate species identification (De Silva et al. 2017a).

Research on fungal comparative genomics has attempted to find correlations in these traits and patterns of gene family evolution; however, such studies typically compare fungi from different genera or even different fungal orders. The C. acutatum species complex contains most of this diversity within a group of relatively closely related species.

Abstract: Colletotrichum acutatum is recognized as a significant anthracnose pathogen affecting a broad range of host plants globally. Numerous studies have reported subgroups within the C. acutatum species complex. A multilocus molecular phylogenetic analysis (ITS, ACT, TUB2, CHS-1, GAPDH, HIS3) involving 331 strains previously identified as C. acutatum and related taxa—spanning various hosts across diverse geographic regions—confirmed the previously recognized molecular groups and identified several novel taxa. Thirty-one species are accepted, of which 21 have not been previously recognized. Colletotrichum orchidophilum clusters basal to the C. acutatum species complex. This complex exhibits high phenotypic diversity, with some species showing preferences for specific hosts or geographic regions, while others are plurivorous and found in multiple areas. In this study, only C. salicis and C. rhombiforme formed sexual morphs in culture; however, sexual morphs have been documented from other taxa, particularly in laboratory crosses, with evidence of hybridization between different species. A new species, C. pseudoacutatum, was also described, resembling C. acutatum but not belonging to its species complex.

The general evolutionary trend emerging in the Colletotrichum acutatum species complex indicates that distinct populations are undergoing significant changes in their host association patterns. This may suggest a role of behavioral switching in mating and changes in host associations. The occurrence of heterothallism appears to influence host range diversity, while isolates capable of homothallism, such as C. salicis and C. phormii, exhibit a narrower host range. This evolutionary trend suggests that the capacity of populations to exchange genetic information leads to genomic rearrangements, thereby increasing genome plasticity and expanding the host spectrum of this pathogen.

Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).

This Perspective article presents a review of the current knowledge on C. acutatum phylogeny, biology, and pathology. It also demonstrates the suitability of C. acutatum for the study of gene family evolution on a fine scale to uncover evolutionary events in the genome associated with the evolution of phenotypic characters important for host interactions.

Fungicides are used to control anthracnose diseases; however, several have become ineffective due to the development of fungicide-resistant strains of the pathogens. Field observations in Florida indicated that growing strawberry plants in soils with low N levels reduced the severity of anthracnose, although this also severely limited fruit production. Both the form of nitrogen and calcium levels influence disease severity. For instance, calcium has been employed to manage soil-borne diseases caused by Pythium spp. on various crops, while nitrate forms of N have been shown to suppress Fusarium wilt in tomatoes, whereas ammonium forms increase disease severity.

Colletotrichum species cause serious diseases in various fruit and vegetable crops worldwide. The presence of the anthracnose fruit rot pathogen, C. acutatum, was first reported on strawberries in the U.S. in 1986 and is now widespread, causing major economic losses in production fields. This fungus had previously been reported as the cause of anthracnose fruit rot in strawberries in Queensland, Australia, in 1965 and is now found in most regions where strawberries are cultivated. Both Colletotrichum fragariae and C. gloeosporioides cause anthracnose crown rot, a destructive disease in strawberry nurseries and production fields in the southeastern U.S. Both species can also lead to petiole lesions and leaf spots. Anthracnose diseases are increasingly significant, resulting in major economic losses for strawberry growers worldwide. The objective of this report is to highlight examples of anthracnose-related research that have enhanced understanding of these diseases and their management.

Previously, Colletotrichum acutatum, not Colletotrichum nymphaeae, was reported to cause anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) in strawberries in Korea. Additionally, cases of anthracnose caused by C. nymphaeae in Korea have been observed in kiwiberries, Japanese plums, and persimmons. Given these findings, it is crucial to investigate whether C. nymphaeae originated from other plants or countries. So far, anthracnose epidemics have affected strawberry nurseries and production fields worldwide. Reports on Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, curated from literature in PubMed and Clarivate combined with fungal database searches (Farr and Rossman, 2022), were compiled to understand the global diversity and occurrence of the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. From our findings, since 1931 until July 9, 2022, there have been over 220 citations and 310 records related to the identification of causal agents of strawberry anthracnose at the genus level of Colletotrichum in 36 countries across six continents, with 282 records providing pathogen identification at the species or species complex level.

The fungi Colletotrichum fragariae and Colletotrichum acutatum cause anthracnose diseases in strawberries. C. fragariae was originally assumed to be the sole causal agent of strawberry anthracnose in the United States until 1986, when Smith and Black reported the presence of C. acutatum on strawberries in the U.S. This fungus had previously been reported to cause anthracnose fruit rot in Queensland, Australia (Simmonds, 1965); however, it may have been present in the U.S. for some time under the name Gloeosporium spp. (Maas, 1984).

Strawberry anthracnose was first reported in China in 1990 (Hu, 1990). Shao (1992) documented the first instance of strawberry anthracnose in Shanghai, identifying the pathogen as Colletotrichum acutatum (Dai et al., 2006). Zhang et al. (2007) expanded on these findings by identifying C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (syn. C. theobromicola) as causal agents based on morphological characteristics. Ren et al. (2008, 2011) concluded that these three species are the main pathogens causing anthracnose in strawberries in China. Crown rot represents the most severe disease issue in many strawberry-producing regions of China (Ren et al., 2008). In the Zhejiang region, nearly 50% of seedling deaths in nurseries and over 40% yield losses in strawberry fields have been recorded (Xie et al., 2010). In 2009, the yield of greenhouse-cultivated strawberries in Donggang City, Liaoning Province, was reduced by over 10% due to crown rot (Wang, 2013). The average incidence of crown rot in greenhouses in Hubei Province was 41.7% in 2011 (Xiang et al., 2012). Due to overlapping characteristics, species delimitation based solely on morphology is challenging in this genus. Employing multi-gene analysis alongside morphology can provide better resolution (Cai et al., 2009; Hyde et al., 2014). Therefore, the objective of this study was to identify the pathogens responsible for strawberry anthracnose in China using a morphological and multi-gene approach.

Conidia germinate either by producing germ tubes and terminal appressoria or by forming sessile appressoria. Appressoria become melanized and develop pores from which host penetration occurs. Two types of infections can develop: (i) intracellular hemibiotrophic, in which infection vesicles or swollen hyphae form within epidermal cells (e.g., on Pinus needles), and (ii) subcuticular, intramural necrotrophic, where cuticular penetration is followed by hyphal proliferation within the cuticle and epidermal cell walls.

Primary inoculum consists of fresh conidia produced in acervuli under favorable conditions of temperature (10 to 30°C for most clades) and moisture (e.g., wetness periods longer than 6 hours) from overwintered sources throughout the cropping season (Moral and Trapero, 2012; Stensvand et al., 2017; Everett et al., 2018). Conidia are splash-dispersed by rain (Denham and Waller, 1981; Chakraborty and Billard, 1995; Madden et al., 1996; Madden, 1997; Guyot et al., 2005; Buirchell et al., 2006), deposited on plant surfaces, and germinate. The germ tubes then produce appressoria, which form infection pegs that penetrate the host cuticle and epidermal cell walls (Perfect et al., 1999). Penetration through stomata or wounds by germ tubes without appressoria formation is rare (Zulqarnain et al., 1996). Infection of epidermal and mesophyll cells occurs after a symptomless biotrophic phase, leading to a necrotic phase in which host cells are killed and secondary hyphae grow both intra- and inter-cellularly (O'Connell et al., 2012). In some cases, the pathogen has a quiescent phase (Peres et al., 2005; Prusky et al., 2013), with the switch to the necrotrophic phase occurring only when host tissue and environmental conditions favor the continuation of the infection cycle. Except for a few species that exist entirely as endophytes, most Colletotrichum species develop a necrotrophic stage at some point in their life cycle (Prusky et al., 2013).

This review focuses on current research into the infection process of Colletotrichum species, with an overall emphasis on how signal transduction influences pre-penetration morphogenesis, including conidiation, conidial attachment, conidial germination, germ tube formation, and appressorial differentiation. Post-penetration biotrophic and necrotrophic growth patterns will also be described. Additionally, intriguing studies involving host specificity and chromosome transfer will be summarized.

The sequence and nature of the infection process, including the initial penetration phase—which may involve a biotrophic or quiescent relationship—and the subsequent development of infection hyphae and colonization of the host varies and is not well understood in most cases. With citrus postbloom fruit drop, the infection strategy on leaves is presumably biotrophic. The disease cycles of anthracnose on different hosts exhibit similar components (Peres et al., 2005; De Silva et al., 2017); they are typically polycyclic, with splash-borne asexual spores (conidia) initiating and spreading epidemics. Other Colletotrichum-related diseases include crown rot in strawberries and black dot disease on the roots of tomatoes and potatoes (Dillard and Cobb, 1997; Dillard and Cobb, 1998; Waller et al., 2002). In the United Kingdom, five species, including C. nigrum (Liu et al. 2013), the more aggressive C. nymphaeae and C. fioriniae, as well as the less aggressive C. godetiae and C. aenigma (Baroncelli et al. 2015), have been reported as strawberry pathogens. retrieved_context: The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).

Numerous light and electron microscopic studies describing plant interactions with Colletotrichum species have been published; however, we have not found studies on the ultrastructure of the C. acutatum and C. fragariae systems in strawberries. A detailed consideration of biotrophy, necrotrophy, and hemibiotrophy is essential for understanding the invasion mechanisms of C. acutatum and C. fragariae. Biotrophy is characterized by the fungus maintaining host cells alive while extracting nutrients from them (9, 16). Necrotrophy involves the fungus killing living host cells before entering their lumina (9, 12, 16, 28). Hemibiotrophy is a phase where the fungus initially engages in a biotrophic phase before transitioning to a necrotrophic phase (9). The initial penetration and invasion processes of a plant host by a fungal pathogen in the context of strawberry anthracnose are crucial for understanding these dynamics.

Although numerous light and electron microscopic studies have described plant interactions with Colletotrichum species, few have focused on the ultrastructure of the C. acutatum and C. fragariae-strawberry systems. Understanding the detailed natures of biotrophy, necrotrophy, and hemibiotrophy is essential for grasping the invasion mechanisms of C. acutatum and C. fragariae. Biotrophy is a condition where the fungus keeps host cells alive while extracting nutrients from them. Necrotrophy refers to the approach of living host cells, killing them before entering their lumina. Hemibiotrophy describes a phase where the fungus initially enters a biotrophic state and then transitions to a necrotrophic phase. The initial penetration and invasion processes of a plant host by a fungal pathogen are critical for understanding these dynamics.

On almond leaves, and presumably fruit, a combination of hemibiotrophic and subcuticular intramural necrotrophic infections occurs, resulting in both intra- and intercellular colonization (21) (Fig. 10D). In this instance, colonization is biotrophic following fungal penetration but shifts to necrotrophy during intercellular growth. This is succeeded by inter- and intracellular colonization and the death of the tissue. The mechanism for the shift from biotrophy to necrotrophy is uncertain; however, C. acutatum, along with other species of Colletotrichum, produces ammonia that causes local pH increases during the transition to necrotrophy (70). In most host-pathogen interactions, the specific cellular-level interactions remain unknown and may represent a combination of strategies, as shown in the preceding descriptions.

C. acutatum and C. fragariae underwent a very brief biotrophic phase (less than 12 hours) before entering their extended necrotrophic phase. Representatives of both species of fungi were observed entering living host cells and developing a matrix comparable to that described in reported biotrophic systems, but they killed the host cells within a few hours. Previous descriptions for other Colletotrichum species cited biotrophy as occurring at a minimum of "less than 24 hours." However, a scenario where a living cell is entered and quickly killed might be considered a modification of necrotrophy, rather than biotrophy or hemibiotrophy.

The timing of the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy depends on the host, its growth stage, environmental conditions (Wharton et al., 2001; Peres et al., 2005), and the phylogenetic clade (De Silva et al., 2017). For instance, the graminicola and destructivum clades have a short biotrophic period, while the acutatum and gloeosporioides clades exhibit a quiescent lifestyle on certain fruit trees like almond and guava (De Silva et al., 2017). For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. The introduction of partially resistant cultivars has also helped mitigate economic losses due to these diseases. Additionally, the development and registration of more effective fungicides for use on strawberries have significantly reduced losses from both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also diminished economic losses due to these diseases. Nevertheless, growers may still experience severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.

Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. For example, benomyl was shown to effectively reduce the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), leading to the ineffectiveness of benomyl for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.

Colletotrichum species are primarily recognized as the causal agents of anthracnose, which occurs on various plant parts, including leaves, stems, flowers, and fruits. The disease cycles of anthracnose on different hosts exhibit similar components (Peres et al., 2005; De Silva et al., 2017); they are typically polycyclic, with splash-borne asexual spores (conidia) initiating and spreading epidemics. Other Colletotrichum-related diseases include crown rot in strawberries and black dot disease on the roots of tomatoes and potatoes (Dillard and Cobb, 1997; Dillard and Cobb, 1998; Waller et al., 2002). Additionally, Colletotrichum species can cause post-harvest diseases, particularly in avocado, almond, and citrus fruits (Prusky, 1996; Ismail and Zhang, 2004; Prusky et al., 2013). In these cases, the pathogens form infection structures (appressoria) on the host but remain dormant within the fruit until after harvest, during which symptoms may emerge (Ismail and Zhang, 2004; Prusky et al., 2013). Several studies have indicated that species within a clade exhibit similar colonization and infection behaviors, with the establishment of quiescence being host- and tissue-specific (Sanders and Korsten, 2003; Damm et al., 2012; Weir et al., 2012; Prusky et al., 2013; Jayawardena et al., 2016; Zakaria, 2021). Furthermore, species within clades have comparable temperature requirements for mycelial growth, conidial germination, infection, and spore production (Salotti et al., 2022). For example, species such as C. gloeosporioides, C. fragariae, C. gossypii, and C. musaebelonging to the gloeosporioides clade show optimum temperatures for mycelial growth, sporulation, conidial germination, and infection between 25 and 32°C (Salotti et al., 2022).

query: How does the switch between biotrophic and necrotrophic lifestyles impact the pathogenicity of plant fungi?
retrieved_context: Biotroph–Necrotroph Combination Lifestyle (Almond, Key Lime): There are several diseases where C. acutatum primarily functions as a necrotroph but can also act as a biotroph, exhibiting a combination of biotrophic and necrotrophic interactions. The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).

O’Connell, R. J., Thon, M. R., Hacquard, S., Amyotte, S. G., Kleemann, J., Torres, M. F., et al. (2012). Lifestyle transitions in plant pathogenic Colletotrichum fungi deciphered by genome and transcriptome analyses. Nat. Genet. 44, 1060–1065. doi: 10.1038/ng.2372.

In recent years, genome sequences for 28 species of Colletotrichum have been published, and comparative genomic studies have concentrated on genes associated with pathogenicity (Gan et al., 2013), host specialization (Baroncelli et al., 2016; Gan et al., 2016), and transitions between biotrophic and necrotrophic lifestyles (O’Connell et al., 2012), as well as between endophytic and parasitic lifestyles (Hacquard et al., 2016; Hiruma et al., 2016). Comparative analyses of secretomes have revealed that most predicted secreted proteins possess enzymatic activity, with many identified as candidate effectors (O’Connell et al., 2012; Gan et al., 2013; Baroncelli et al., 2016; Sanz-Martín et al., 2016). The host range of Colletotrichum species seems to be linked to gene loss or gain in families encoding carbohydrate-active enzymes (CAZymes) and proteases (Baroncelli et al., 2016). Notably, gene families encoding proteases and carbohydrate-degrading enzymes are significantly expanded in Colletotrichum compared to other Sordariomycetes (Gan et al., 2013; Baroncelli et al., 2016), indicating the increased importance of these families in the infection processes of Colletotrichum species. Transcriptional profiling experiments have also shown that CAZymes, along with other classes of secreted proteins, are highly modulated during the infection process, further implicating them as critical players in pathogenicity (Kleemann et al., 2012; O’Connell et al., 2012).

Our model is general in that it has one conceptual structure that incorporates the key epidemiological components of anthracnose diseases. Although Colletotrichum spp. exhibit various lifestyles categorized as necrotrophic, hemibiotrophic, latent or quiescent, and endophytic—with hemibiotrophic being the most common (Peres et al., 2005; De Silva et al., 2017)—all species have a necrotrophic stage (Prusky et al., 2013), except for a few species that live entirely as endophytes (e.g., some species in the gloeosporioides clade on Salacia and Camellia; Bhagya et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2015). The timing of the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy depends on the host, its growth stage, environmental conditions (Wharton et al., 2001; Peres et al., 2005), and the phylogenetic clade (De Silva et al., 2017). For instance, the graminicola and destructivum clades have a short biotrophic period, while the acutatum and gloeosporioides clades exhibit a quiescent lifestyle on certain fruit trees like almond and guava (De Silva et al., 2017). Our model accounts for the common attributes of Colletotrichum lifestyles in terms of: (i) a reproductive (asexual) stage, which occurs on the host plant or in plant debris; (ii) infection caused by conidia; (iii) an asymptomatic (biotrophic) stage that can be either short or extended, depending on the incubation period; (iv) a necrotrophic stage in which host cells are invaded and killed, leading to the appearance of symptoms (lesions in our model); and (v) a sporulation stage, i.e., the production of secondary inoculum on lesions.

Prusky et al. (2013) discussed the quiescent and necrotrophic lifestyle choices of these fungi during postharvest disease development. They emphasized how these lifestyle choices influence disease outcomes. The distinct population structure of Colletotrichum species associated with olive anthracnose in the Algarve region reflects a complex host-pathogen relationship.

On almond leaves, and presumably fruit, a combination of hemibiotrophic and subcuticular intramural necrotrophic infections occurs, resulting in both intra- and intercellular colonization (21) (Fig. 10D). In this instance, colonization is biotrophic following fungal penetration but shifts to necrotrophy during intercellular growth. This is succeeded by inter- and intracellular colonization and the death of the tissue. The mechanism for the shift from biotrophy to necrotrophy is uncertain; however, C. acutatum, along with other species of Colletotrichum, produces ammonia that causes local pH increases during the transition to necrotrophy (70). In most host-pathogen interactions, the specific cellular-level interactions remain unknown and may represent a combination of strategies, as shown in the preceding descriptions.

Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Meta-analyses have revealed that C. acutatum s.l. strains are associated with infections in hundreds of species from over 90 genera of plants (Magnoliophyta: monocotyledons and dicotyledons, Pinophyta, and Pteridophyta), along with at least two insect species (Dufresne et al., 2000; Thon et al., 2002; Wharton and Diéguez-Uribeondo, 2004; O’Connell et al., 2012; Marcelino et al., 2008; Mascarin et al., 2016). In a few cases, associations have been noted with marine ecosystems (Manire et al., 2002; Namikoshi et al., 2002). There appears to be little to no evidence of co-evolution between host and pathogen, particularly in cultivated fruit systems like strawberry and olive, which are susceptible to many members of this species complex (Jayawardena et al., 2016).

Another significant finding from comparative studies is that lifestyle and host preference do not correlate with phylogenetic relationships (Baroncelli et al., 2016; Gan et al., 2016). A comparison of the genomes of the endophyte C. tofieldiae and the closely related pathogen C. incanum indicated that the transition to an endophytic lifestyle was associated with a reduction in the number of predicted effectors and an expansion of chitin-binding and secondary metabolism-related proteins (Hacquard et al., 2016). In contrast, relatively distantly related members of the C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides species complexes exhibit remarkably similar repertoires of carbohydrate-active enzymes and secreted proteases (Baroncelli et al., 2016). This observation suggests that these gene families evolved recently and independently in these two phylogenetically separated lineages (Baroncelli et al., 2016; Gan et al., 2016). Further comparative analyses of the genomes within the C. acutatum species complex revealed that necrosis and ethylene-inducing peptide 1-like proteins were twice as abundant as in the other fungi studied. The large number of these genes underscores their potential significance in the pathogenicity of these species.

Colletotrichum species have been reported as endophytes, epiphytes, saprobes, plant pathogens, and even human pathogens (Sutton, 1992; TeBeest et al., 1997; Cano et al., 2004; Kumar and Hyde, 2004; Photita et al., 2004, 2005; Promputtha et al., 2007). Species that cause serious plant diseases are often isolated as endophytes from healthy plants and have also been identified as saprobes on dead plant material (Photita et al., 2001; Kumar and Hyde, 2004; Liu et al., 2007; Promputtha et al., 2007; Damm et al., 2009; Prihastuti et al., 2009). In many cases, the same species have been recorded with several lifestyles; however, due to the ambiguity of species identification, it is not always clear whether they are definitively the same species. The question of how and if taxa change their lifestyles from non-pathogenic to pathogenic still needs to be addressed and remains an important unresolved issue in the study of Colletotrichum.

query: What specific factors might explain why C. acutatum did not produce disease symptoms on most of the tested plants, even though conidia were recovered from them?
retrieved_context: Strawberry, eggplant, tomato, and pepper plants were inoculated with a conidial suspension of C. acutatum derived from strawberry. Conidia were recovered from all plants over a 2- to 3-month period, regardless of whether overhead or drip irrigation was used (see Fig. 2). The number of conidia recovered from strawberry was comparable to that from the other plants at all time points and, in most cases, the differences were not significant (P < 0.05) across the different plant species, although disease symptoms were observed only on the strawberry plants. Significant numbers of conidia were still recovered from the plants at the end of the experiment, indicating that the survival potential of the fungus on all plant species exceeded 3 months.

In Israel, inoculation of isolates of C. acutatum from anemone and strawberry into each host resulted in typical anthracnose symptoms on both plant species. Molecular studies indicated that the isolates from the two hosts were similar and formed a single genetic subgroup. Isolates of C. acutatum were recovered from pepper, eggplant, tomato, bean, as well as from weeds of the genera Vicia and Conyza; however, disease symptoms occurred only on strawberry. C. acutatum isolates from tulip tree in Argentina were also pathogenic to strawberry fruit. Thus, strawberry isolates of C. acutatum can parasitize and cause disease on other hosts or, alternatively, survive on other crops and weeds without producing symptoms.

The fungus was shown to survive on asymptomatic leaves of several plant species under greenhouse conditions (12). Studies suggested that symptomless foliage might play an important role in the anthracnose disease cycle, acting both as a refuge for fungal survival and as a source of inoculum for fruit and flower infections (12, 19, 33). Temperature and wetness have been reported to affect mycelial growth (1, 7, 11, 21, 37, 39), as well as the germination and sporulation of C. acutatum on agar (11), and its infection and sporulation on fruit (18, 39). However, similar studies on strawberry foliage have not been conducted. Additionally, the production of secondary conidia was not addressed in earlier research.

In strawberries, C. acutatum is typically introduced into production fields from nurseries. While some plants may exhibit symptoms, often the pathogen is introduced through asymptomatic leaves or petioles, likely as appressoria or quiescent infections. It remains unclear whether quiescent infections develop into lesions or if appressoria germinate to produce conidia. However, conidia of C. acutatum can generate several secondary conidia from each deposited conidium on the leaf surface. This suggests that the fungus is reproducing by utilizing nutrients on the leaf surface rather than relying on reserves from the original conidium. In these instances, it appears that the fungus is growing as an epiphyte rather than producing quiescent infections.

In inoculations conducted under controlled greenhouse conditions, C. acutatum from strawberry was isolated from inoculated plants that did not exhibit disease symptoms but maintained virulence on strawberry. The fungus was detected by a plating method both on and inside inoculated leaves at various time points after plant inoculation. The authenticity of the isolates as C. acutatum was validated by PCR using C. acutatum-specific primers. The PCR technique proved accurate and sensitive enough to detect the pathogen in inoculated tissues within 24 hours post-inoculation. This method is valuable for detecting C. acutatum in the tissues of various plant species, indicating that the fungus can exhibit both epiphytic and endophytic lifestyles without causing visible disease symptoms. PCR and fungal isolation data indicate that the pathogen can remain viable for extended periods within the tissues of various plant species without inducing disease symptoms. Although the experiments were concluded after three months for technical reasons, the final levels of inoculum in the examined tissues and the decay curves suggest that the pathogen had the potential to inhabit the infected plants for much longer periods. Furthermore, it has been shown that C. acutatum from strawberry can survive for nine months within plant debris in soil.

The epiphytic behavior of C. acutatum on symptomless foliage may play a critical role in the strawberry anthracnose disease cycle. Recent studies have shown that C. acutatum can produce secondary conidia on strawberry leaves without visible symptom development and can persist on symptomless foliage of strawberries and weeds for several weeks. As a result, symptomless leaves may act as a source of inoculum for strawberry anthracnose. Similarly, symptomless foliage of tomato and citrus has been reported to provide inoculum for diseases caused by C. coccodes and C. acutatum, respectively.

This study provides strong evidence that C. acutatum can become established, persist, and produce inoculum on symptomless strawberry leaves under a range of temperatures and intermittent wetness periods. In addition to our previous work at 26°C under continuous wetness (19), we have now shown that secondary conidia and appressoria may be produced under environmental conditions typical of many temperate strawberry-producing areas in the world. The survival of C. acutatum on strawberry leaves has implications for long-distance dissemination on transplants, as well as the proliferation and dissemination of the fungus within production fields. Furthermore, asymptomatic foliage of other plant species, including weeds, has been recently suggested as an additional inoculum source for C. acutatum (12). The environmental biology of C. acutatum on symptomless foliage should therefore be considered when developing management practices for strawberry anthracnose.

Symptomless foliage harbors inoculum for fruit and flower infections by several Colletotrichum species (7, 21, 28). Pantidou and Schroeder (21) demonstrated that conidia of C. phomoides harvested from symptomless tomato leaves could cause infections on tomato fruit. In citrus, C. acutatum survives on leaves as quiescent appressoria (28, 30), which can be stimulated to germinate and produce secondary conidia, serving as inoculum for flower infections. It has also been suggested that quiescent infections on strawberry leaves may provide inoculum for strawberry anthracnose epidemics (23). However, the potential for inoculum production on symptomless strawberry leaves has not been investigated. A better understanding of the ecology of C. acutatum on strawberry foliage before the onset of fruit rot symptoms may yield insights to improve management strategies for strawberry anthracnose.

A difference between the mean disease severity ratings of Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae in both experiments confirmed previous findings (Smith and Black, 1990) that C. acutatum produces less severe plant disease reactions than C. fragariae. Colletotrichum acutatum is occasionally isolated from the crowns of dying plants in the field, but it primarily acts as a fruit rot organism with the potential to cause crown rot.

Our evidence suggests that Colletotrichum acutatum inoculum can survive and multiply on symptomless strawberry leaves, and that the production of secondary conidia may increase inoculum when susceptible tissue is not available. Greater awareness of the surreptitious fungal dynamics on symptomless plants may also justify changes in currently recommended control strategies. For instance, early fungicide applications might effectively reduce initial inoculum production on developing plants, thereby decreasing subsequent epidemic development on fruit.

Nitrogen is absorbed by plant roots in two forms: ammonium (NH4-N) and nitrate (NO3-N). Ammonium ions are produced in soils through the breakdown of organic matter (OM), manures, urea, or ammonium-containing fertilizers. Nitrogen can be lost from the soil in several ways, including volatilization, anaerobic denitrification, and leaching. Normally, ammonium does not leach from the soil because its positive charge is attracted to and “held” by the negative charges present on the surfaces of clay and humus particles. However, when ammonium is transformed into nitrate, it loses its positive charge, and the soil no longer retains the available nitrogen unless positive charges are present (anion exchange capacity). Water percolating through the soil profile may leach and deplete mobile nitrate from the upper layers to the lower layers and even into the groundwater if leaching is excessive. Such excessive nitrate leaching is often a consequence of inadequate nitrogen fertilizer management.

However, with increased production, many fungal diseases have emerged as significant challenges, negatively impacting fruit yield and quality (Mass 1998, Smith 2008). Among these, anthracnose, caused by species of Colletotrichum, is one of the most critical diseases affecting strawberries.

Although strawberries are considered a minor crop, they provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. The use of transplants from northern nurseries is crucial to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to ensure that plants have undergone sufficient natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.

However, in China, the identification of Colletotrichum species on mango has mainly relied on conidial morphology and ITS sequences, and the combined data remain limited and insufficient to distinguish closely related taxa in the six species complexes mentioned above. Previous research on Colletotrichum species affecting mango has primarily focused on samples from small and fragmented provincial areas, leading to poor representation of the actual species diversity in the vast mango-growing regions of China.

The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex contains taxa with significant biological, morphological, and genetic diversity (Sutton, 1992; Hyde et al., 2009). Some of these taxa have been designated as separate species, such as C. fragariae (Johnston et al., 2008). The ITS region has a limited ability to discriminate clades within this group; hence, a more appropriate biomarker is required for barcoding. The ideal locus for use in barcoding should have low heterogeneity within species, yet enough variation to allow maximum separation of different species. The first requirement facilitates easy grouping and identification of strains from the same species, while the second minimizes misidentifications. It is also important that the gene can be easily sequenced for all species and does not require specific primers for each group (Seifert, 2009; Gilmore et al., 2009; Chen et al., 2009).

Phylogenetic analyses using molecular markers have revealed that many members of the genus Colletotrichum can be grouped into independent lineages with similar evolutionary histories (Cai et al. 2011). Several of these lineages have now been systematically classified as species complexes comprising closely related sibling species (Weir et al. 2012). Many species within the C. gloeosporioides species complex have previously been classified as C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, largely based on morphological characteristics and known host range (Hyde et al. 2009). Additionally, the study by Weir et al. (2012) showed that ITS sequences, which have long been used to classify fungal species, are not very reliable in distinguishing different species within this species complex. However, different species do not require the same level of control when encountered in the field (Prihastuti et al. 2009).

A polyphasic approach combining multilocus phylogenetic analysis with recognizable phenotypic characteristics is recommended for accurate species identification within the Colletotrichum genus. According to Weir et al., internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequences alone are not reliable for distinguishing different species within the C. gloeosporioides species complex. Additional loci recommended for identifying Colletotrichum species include actin (ACT), calmodulin (CAL), chitin synthase-1 (CHS-1), glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), and β-tubulin (TUB2).

The genus Colletotrichum represents a large number of economically important Ascomycete fungi that collectively cause anthracnose disease or leaf blights on significant agricultural crops and ornamental plants worldwide. Colletotrichum spp. often serve as models in studies ranging from pathogenic development and differentiation to plant-microbe interactions. During establishment and colonization of host plants, members of this genus uniquely acquire nutrients via both biotrophy and necrotrophy. Thus, in a single interaction, these fungal pathogens exhibit two modes of nutrient acquisition: initially, nutrients are acquired from living cells, after which a necrotrophic phase is initiated, allowing the same fungus to obtain nutrients from dead cells killed by the fungus. A given species of this genus can exhibit both strategies separately or concurrently. Additionally, these fungi develop a series of specialized infection-related structures, including germ tubes, appressoria, primary intracellular hyphae, and secondary necrotrophic hyphae. Therefore, Colletotrichum species are experimentally attractive organisms for studying the molecular, biochemical, and cellular basis of fungal pathogenicity, development, and signal transduction (see Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Prusky et al., 1999).

Abstract: Fragaria ananassa (common name: strawberry) is a globally cultivated hybrid species belonging to the Rosaceae family. Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato (s.l.) is considered the second most economically important pathogen worldwide affecting strawberries. A collection of 148 Colletotrichum spp. isolates, including 67 C. acutatum s.l. isolates associated with the phytosanitary history of UK strawberry production, was used to characterize multilocus genetic variation of this pathogen in the UK, relative to additional reference isolates representing a worldwide sampling of the fungus diversity. Evidence indicates that three different species—C. nymphaeae, C. godetiae, and C. fioriniae—are associated with strawberry production in the UK, corresponding to previously designated genetic groups A2, A4, and A3, respectively. Among these species, 12 distinct haplotypes were identified, suggesting multiple introductions into the country. A subset of isolates was also used to assess aggressiveness in causing disease on strawberry plants and fruits. Isolates belonging to C. nymphaeae, C. godetiae, and C. fioriniae, representative of the UK anthracnose pathogen populations, showed variation in their aggressiveness. Among the three species, C. nymphaeae and C. fioriniae appeared to be more aggressive compared to C. godetiae. This study highlights the genetic and pathogenic heterogeneity of the C. acutatum s.l. populations introduced into the UK linked to strawberry production.
