query: What are some limitations of using ITS sequencing for fungal taxonomy?
retrieved_context: Molecular tools are increasingly being utilized for day-to-day identification by biosecurity officers and plant pathology researchers, highlighting the need for a taxonomy that accurately reflects genetically resolved groups, along with simple and reliable protocols for identifying those taxa. The internal transcribed spacer region (ITS) has been proposed as the official fungal barcoding gene (Schoch et al. 2012). While ITS is useful at the species complex level, it is ineffective at resolving species within the C. gloeosporioides complex, identifying only 10 out of 22 accepted species. This limitation arises from the low number of base changes in the ITS region across the complex, where species are often differentiated by just one or two base changes. In some cases, random variation in the ITS sequence within or between species results in certain species being indistinguishable. Examples of taxa with identical ITS sequences include C. clidemiae, C. tropicale, C. ti, and some others.

The recent epitypification of C. gloeosporioides marked an important milestone for taxonomic studies of the complex (Cannon et al., 2008). Since then, the availability of living ex-type strains and sequence data has provided a solid reference for comparison with isolates. However, criteria for species delimitation have been debated over the years, with Colletotrichum serving as a notable example (Cannon et al., 2008). Until recently, single-locus phylogenies dominated the molecular systematics of the C. gloeosporioides complex, despite their limited resolving ability (Sreenivasaprasad et al., 1993, 1996; Johnston and Jones, 1997; Nguyen et al., 2009; Polashock et al., 2009). Specifically, the internal transcribed spacers (ITS) flanking the 5.8S ribosomal RNA represent the most widely sequenced region in Colletotrichum phylogenetic studies. Consequently, ITS-based C. gloeosporioides specific primers (Mills et al., 1992) have been extensively utilized for identifying Colletotrichum fungi over the past 10 to 15 years. However, there are significant concerns regarding the resolving power of ITS for closely related species (Cai et al., 2009; Crouch et al., 2009b). Recognizing the limitations of ITS and similar markers has led to an increasing necessity for the development and use of more informative loci. Molecular phylogenetic analyses using multilocus datasets are now providing an objective approach to determining species boundaries.

Accepted 20 August 2007. To overcome taxonomic problems associated with traditional identification methods, DNA sequence analyses were used to characterize and resolve the taxonomic complexity of some fungal genera, such as Fusarium (O’Donnell et al., 1998), Pestalotiopsis (Jeewon et al., 2004), and Colletotrichum (Sreenivasaprasad et al., 1996; Photita et al., 2005). Cannon et al. (2000) stated that data derived from nucleic acid analyses should provide the most reliable framework for classifying Colletotrichum, as DNA characters are not directly influenced by environmental factors. In particular, sequence analysis of the ITS regions proved useful in studying the phylogenetic relationships of Colletotrichum species (Sreenivasaprasad et al., 1996; Photita et al., 2005).

(2009), where GAPDH, CAL, and ACT performed well, while CHS-1, ITS, and TEF (EF1α) performed poorly. However, the analysis by Cai et al. With the final classification presented here, none of the genes analyzed provides an effective barcode on its own across the entire complex. With GS, C. aotearoa, C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro, and C. siamense are paraphyletic. GAPDH is the easiest of all the tested genes to amplify and sequence; however, when using this gene, GS sequences are needed to distinguish C. fructicola from C. alienum and C. aeschynomenes from C. siamense, while C. tropicale is paraphyletic. In the species descriptions, we provide notes on which genes are best for genetic identification. These summaries are presented in Table 4, which outlines the effectiveness of all species and genes. Benzimidazoles are commonly applied as dips or sprays to inhibit the anthracnose-causing fungus, Colletotrichum spp. [141], but the large-scale and continuous use of fungicides has led to the development of fungal resistance. For instance, benzimidazole-resistant Colletotrichum has been detected in mangoes and bananas [140]. Additionally, the excessive use of fungicides negatively impacts human health and the environment, as chemical residues often contaminate soil and water [142]. Biocontrol offers an alternative, non-toxic method for managing fruit crop anthracnose. Biocontrol agents, such as antagonistic microbes including yeast, bacteria, and filamentous fungi (particularly Trichoderma spp.), have shown promising results and are gaining popularity for their direct application to fruit surfaces post-harvest [143].

Additionally, multisite fungicides such as captan, thiram, and chlorothalonil, which have been available for many decades, remain effective in reducing strawberry anthracnose incidence (Mertely et al. 2018). Chlorothalonil is only registered for nonbearing nurseries when flowers and fruit are absent, yet our surveys indicated that its usage is significantly lower compared to newer single-site fungicides. Due to their efficacy and low resistance risk, multisite fungicides should be the mainstay for disease control in strawberry nurseries. Other non-chemical alternatives, such as heat (Wang et al. 2017) and ultraviolet treatments (Onofre et al. 2017), are currently under investigation and could serve as valuable tools for disease management, reducing the reliance on single-site fungicides.

This complex exhibits high phenotypic diversity, with some species showing preferences for specific hosts or geographic regions, while others are plurivorous and found in multiple areas. In this study, only C. salicis and C. rhombiforme formed sexual morphs in culture; however, sexual morphs have been documented from other taxa, particularly in laboratory crosses, with evidence of hybridization between different species. Many pathogens are sensitive to temperature, rainfall, and humidity (Harvell et al. 2002; Wilson et al. 1990). Temperature is a critical factor influencing plant disease epidemics, as it can affect spore germination, infection rates, latent periods, sporulation, spore survival, and host resistance to various pathogens (Bonde et al. 2012; Wilson et al. 1990). High temperatures and their frequency can delay or even prevent the onset of plant diseases (Bonde et al. 2012, 2013). Conversely, the adaptation of pathogens to temperature plays a vital role in disease emergence.

The occurrence of species on strawberry has been well researched due to the former status of C. acutatum as a regulated quarantine pathogen. We found that strains from this host belong to six different clades within the C. acutatum species complex: C. simmondsii (three strains from Australia), C. nymphaeae (38 strains, mostly from Europe and the USA), C. fioriniae (seven strains from New Zealand, the UK, and the USA), C. godetiae (10 strains, all from Europe), C. acutatum s. str. (one strain from Australia), and C. salicis (four strains from New Zealand). A study by MacKenzie et al. (2009) demonstrated that strains from strawberry were more aggressive to strawberry than strains from Vaccinium. Based on TUB2 sequences generated by those authors, the strains from strawberry were assigned to C. nymphaeae, while the strains from Vaccinium were assigned to C. fioriniae. The apparent differences in pathogenicity may not stem from the different hosts but rather from the fact that the strains studied belong to different species. To our knowledge, C. acutatum s. str. has rarely been found in Europe, and then mostly on ornamental plants. So far, it has only been isolated from strawberry in Australia. Members of the C. acutatum species complex have been well-documented from agricultural and natural hosts worldwide (Perfect et al., 1999; Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005). The scientific community has long studied the biomolecular processes regulating this lifestyle, especially those related to the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy. The species complex has a very wide host range. Colletotrichum acutatum was identified by Simmonds (1965) and validated by the same author in 1968. A similar situation applies to safflower (Carthamus tinctorius), where only strains of C. chrysanthemi were pathogenic to safflower. Strains genetically close but belonging to different species were not pathogenic on the same host (Peres et al., 2005; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005; Baroncelli et al., 2015a). While approximately 7% of the scientific literature on Colletotrichum from 1991 to 2000 addressed C. acutatum, this proportion rose to 18% in the following decade, depicting C. acutatum as a “popular” entity (based on an ISI Web of Science search of 1839 publications during 1991–2010 containing “Colletotrichum” in the title). Other members of the species complex with a strong relationship to specific hosts include C. phormii, pathogenic to Phormium spp., and C. tamarilloi, the causal agent of tamarillo (Solanum betaceum) anthracnose (Baroncelli, 2012; Damm et al., 2012).

Isolates of Colletotrichum species have been disseminated worldwide, likely through international plant exchanges, as their genetic polymorphism and geographical origins are not correlated (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 2002; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005).

The perceived lack of host specificity in the C. acutatum complex likely has multiple causes, but a significant issue stems from inadequate identification practices in pathology studies. Many investigations still avoid including sequence-based evidence or rely solely on ITS sequences, with only a few depositing adequate voucher material. This leads to less rigorous name usage than is necessary, resulting in misleading outcomes and poor comparability between studies. It must be acknowledged that many, if not most, of the species recognized through multigene analyses do not seem to be restricted to particular plants.

The internal transcribed spacer region (ITS) has been proposed as the official fungal barcoding gene (Schoch et al. 2012). While ITS is useful at the species complex level, it is ineffective at resolving species within the C. gloeosporioides complex, identifying only 10 out of 22 accepted species. This limitation arises from the low number of base changes in the ITS region across the complex, where species are often differentiated by just one or two base changes. The identification of cryptic taxa is progressing rapidly, and groups of fungi, including important plant pathogens, are primarily classified using molecular data-based phylogenetic inference. For instance, the C. acutatum, C. boninense, and C. gloeosporioides species complexes now each contain over 20 species. Several Colletotrichum species capable of causing strawberry anthracnose in temperate regions have been reported; however, knowledge of the composition of pathogen populations in tropical and subtropical regions remains limited.

To overcome taxonomic problems associated with traditional identification methods, DNA sequence analyses were used to characterize and resolve the taxonomic complexity of some fungal genera, such as Fusarium (O’Donnell et al., 1998), Pestalotiopsis (Jeewon et al., 2004), and Colletotrichum (Sreenivasaprasad et al., 1996; Photita et al., 2005). Cannon et al. (2000) stated that data derived from nucleic acid analyses should provide the most reliable framework for classifying Colletotrichum, as DNA characters are not directly influenced by environmental factors. In particular, sequence analysis of the ITS regions proved useful in studying the phylogenetic relationships of Colletotrichum species (Sreenivasaprasad et al., 1996; Photita et al., 2005).

The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex contains taxa with significant biological, morphological, and genetic diversity (Sutton, 1992; Hyde et al., 2009). Some of these taxa have been designated as separate species, such as C. fragariae (Johnston et al., 2008). The ITS region has a limited ability to discriminate clades within this group; hence, a more appropriate biomarker is required for barcoding. The ideal locus for use in barcoding should have low heterogeneity within species, yet enough variation to allow maximum separation of different species. The first requirement facilitates easy grouping and identification of strains from the same species, while the second minimizes misidentifications. It is also important that the gene can be easily sequenced for all species and does not require specific primers for each group (Seifert, 2009; Gilmore et al., 2009; Chen et al., 2009).

A detailed study of the C. boninense complex has revealed that even recently recognized species of Colletotrichum may obscure extensive molecular variation and may contain multiple taxa with distinct evolutionary origins. The ongoing debate regarding whether these segregate taxa should be classified at the species or infraspecific level (Cannon et al. 2008) remains unresolved. However, recent trends favor recognizing them as independent species. This approach simplifies nomenclature but may limit practical value for applied mycologists and plant pathologists, as the names do not necessarily indicate host specificity or nutritional/biological strategies. Unfortunately, many of these species cannot currently be reliably identified using single diagnostic (barcoding) sequences, making this aspect of their systematics a high priority for future research. On a positive note, there is now significantly more information regarding the phylogenetic components of the C. boninense complex.

The recent epitypification of C. gloeosporioides marked an important milestone for taxonomic studies of the complex (Cannon et al., 2008). Since then, the availability of living ex-type strains and sequence data has provided a solid reference for comparison with isolates. However, criteria for species delimitation have been debated over the years, with Colletotrichum serving as a notable example (Cannon et al., 2008). Until recently, single-locus phylogenies dominated the molecular systematics of the C. gloeosporioides complex, despite their limited resolving ability (Sreenivasaprasad et al., 1993, 1996; Johnston and Jones, 1997; Nguyen et al., 2009; Polashock et al., 2009). Consequently, ITS-based C. gloeosporioides specific primers (Mills et al., 1992) have been extensively utilized for identifying Colletotrichum fungi over the past 10 to 15 years. However, there are significant concerns regarding the resolving power of ITS for closely related species (Cai et al., 2009; Crouch et al., 2009b). Recognizing the limitations of ITS and similar markers has led to an increasing necessity for the development and use of more informative loci. Molecular phylogenetic analyses using multilocus datasets are now providing an objective approach to determining species boundaries.

Furthermore, unlike many undescribed or poorly understood lineages in this complex, the species we studied are well characterized and recognized through multilocus phylogenetic and morphological studies. This is crucial when evaluating the utility of newly developed molecular tools for systematic purposes. retrieved_context: Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum species is one of the most destructive diseases affecting strawberry production worldwide. Fungi of the genus Colletotrichum, which are ancient and co-evolved with flowering plants, rank eighth among the ten most economically important fungal pathogens and have diversified to adapt to various hosts. Since its first report in the United States in 1931, strawberry anthracnose has spread globally, resulting in devastating economic, social, and ecological consequences. In many ways, producing organic strawberries is largely impractical because of this disease. Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries have been extensively characterized. This review aims to provide an accurate inventory of these species by revisiting their discovery history over the past 90 years. A total of 23 Colletotrichum species, clustered into five species complexes and two singleton taxa, have been accepted as strawberry pathogens with a global occurrence illustrated. The relative prevalence of distinct Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries has been systematically analyzed in China. Finally, the host range of the two prevailing species, C. fructicola and C. siamense, which cause significant damage globally, is summarized, with the goal of improving diagnostic accuracy and anthracnose management in agricultural ecosystems.

Strawberry anthracnose was first reported in China in 1990 (Hu, 1990). Shao (1992) documented the first instance of strawberry anthracnose in Shanghai, identifying the pathogen as Colletotrichum acutatum (Dai et al., 2006). Zhang et al. (2007) expanded on these findings by identifying C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (syn. C. theobromicola) as causal agents based on morphological characteristics. Ren et al. (2008, 2011) concluded that these three species are the main pathogens causing anthracnose in strawberries in China. Crown rot represents the most severe disease issue in many strawberry-producing regions of China (Ren et al., 2008). In the Zhejiang region, nearly 50% of seedling deaths in nurseries and over 40% yield losses in strawberry fields have been recorded (Xie et al., 2010). In 2009, the yield of greenhouse-cultivated strawberries in Donggang City, Liaoning Province, was reduced by over 10% due to crown rot (Wang, 2013). The average incidence of crown rot in greenhouses in Hubei Province was 41.7% in 2011 (Xiang et al., 2012). However, most studies conducted in China regarding this disease have primarily relied on morphological and single-gene (mainly ITS) analysis (Dai et al., 2006; Ren et al., 2008, 2011). Due to overlapping characteristics, species delimitation based solely on morphology is challenging in this genus. Employing multi-gene analysis alongside morphology can provide better resolution (Cai et al., 2009; Hyde et al., 2014). Therefore, the objective of this study was to identify the pathogens responsible for strawberry anthracnose in China using a morphological and multi-gene approach.

Ji et al. (2022) reported that a total of 11 Colletotrichum species have been identified as pathogens of strawberries in China, which will be comprehensively introduced later. In Europe, strawberry anthracnose is largely attributed to the C. acutatum complex. Strains of C. godetiae infectious to strawberries have been documented in Ireland and Norway (Baroncelli et al. 2015; Chethana et al. 2016). In Denmark, C. nymphaeae is the only Colletotrichum species reported as a strawberry pathogen (Braganca et al. 2016), with similar reports from Bulgaria (Bobev et al. 2002; Jelev et al. 2008; Jayawardena et al. 2016b), Switzerland, and Portugal (Baroncelli et al. 2015). Both C. godetiae and C. nymphaeae were identified as strawberry pathogens in the Netherlands (Baroncelli et al. 2015; Jayawardena et al. 2016b) and Spain (Damm et al. 2012; Baroncelli et al. 2015).

The first formal report of strawberry anthracnose in China was made by Hu (1990) at the fifth annual conference of the Chinese Society of Plant Pathology, which took place in Jiangsu Province. In Shanghai, C. fragariae and C. acutatum were identified as strawberry pathogens (Shao 1992; Ye et al. 1997). Subsequently, fruit rot caused by C. acutatum was reported in Shanghai based on morphological identification (Dai et al. 2006). Molecular analysis using ITS sequences facilitated the identification of 16 C. gloeosporioides isolates and one C. acutatum isolate collected from 1996 to 2006 in Shanghai (Ren et al. 2008). Based on ITS sequences and restriction enzyme digestion, 31 Colletotrichum isolates collected from diseased strawberries between 2006 and 2007 in Shanghai and Zhejiang were identified as C. acutatum, C. gloeosporioides, and C. fragariae (Xie et al. 2010). A study collected 114 fungal isolates from the C. gloeosporioides complex from diseased strawberries during 2010 to 2013 in Zhejiang Province, though they were not distinguished at the species level (Lin et al. 2016).

In a study conducted in Zhejiang province, China, the pathogenicity of various Colletotrichum isolates was assessed on wounded and non-wounded strawberry leaves. Most isolates, such as ZJE-3, exhibited strong pathogenicity on wounded leaves but weak pathogenicity on non-wounded leaves (Supplementary Fig. S3). A phylogenetic analysis was performed using five genes (GAPDH, CAL, CHS-1, ACT, and ITS) to identify 91 different isolates from strawberry anthracnose samples. The species identified were C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. aenigma, and C. siamense, all belonging to the C. gloeosporioides species complex. This is the first report of C. siamense causing strawberry anthracnose in Zhejiang, where it was found to be the second most common species. Although originally described from coffee plantations in Thailand, C. siamense has a wide geographical distribution and diverse host range. The study noted variability in its morphological characteristics, suggesting environmental conditions may influence mycelial growth. Different colony types were observed, with a generally grayish-white appearance and slow hyphal growth under the tested culture conditions. The pathogenicity varied among C. siamense isolates, indicating a need for further research on their pathogenesis.

All identified Colletotrichum species causing strawberry anthracnose belonged to the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex. Among these, we identified 48 isolates of C. fructicola, 21 isolates of C. siamense, 13 isolates of C. gloeosporioides, and 9 isolates of C. aenigma. This is the first report of C. siamense causing strawberry anthracnose in Zhejiang Province. C. fructicola was identified as the most dominant species responsible for strawberry anthracnose in the region.

C. siamense and C. fructicola are recognized as the primary pathogens responsible for strawberry anthracnose crown rot in the Asia-Pacific region (Nam et al. 2013; Han et al. 2016; Jayawardena et al. 2016a; Gan et al. 2017; Hirayama et al. 2018; Gupta et al. 2019; Chen et al. 2020; Chung et al. 2020; Zhang et al. 2020; Jian et al. 2021; Zhong et al. 2021; Oliveira et al. 2022; Wang et al. 2022). Both are cosmopolitan fungi that can adapt to a diverse array of host plants, with higher occurrences reported in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly in Asia compared to other continents.

Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In vitro and greenhouse trials have been conducted to identify fungicides to which Colletotrichum pathogens have developed resistance (LaMondia, 1993, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a, 1992b; Smith and Black, 1991, 1992, 1993). In recent years, genome sequences for 28 species of Colletotrichum have been published, and comparative genomic studies have concentrated on genes associated with pathogenicity (Gan et al., 2013), host specialization (Baroncelli et al., 2016; Gan et al., 2016), and transitions between biotrophic and necrotrophic lifestyles (O’Connell et al., 2012), as well as between endophytic and parasitic lifestyles (Hacquard et al., 2016; Hiruma et al., 2016). Comparative analyses of secretomes have revealed that most predicted secreted proteins possess enzymatic activity, with many identified as candidate effectors (O’Connell et al., 2012; Gan et al., 2013; Baroncelli et al., 2016; Sanz-Martín et al., 2016). The host range of Colletotrichum species seems to be linked to gene loss or gain in families encoding carbohydrate-active enzymes (CAZymes) and proteases (Baroncelli et al., 2016). Notably, gene families encoding proteases and carbohydrate-degrading enzymes are significantly expanded in Colletotrichum compared to other Sordariomycetes (Gan et al., 2013; Baroncelli et al., 2016), indicating the increased importance of these families in the infection processes of Colletotrichum species. Transcriptional profiling experiments have also shown that CAZymes, along with other classes of secreted proteins, are highly modulated during the infection process, further implicating them as critical players in pathogenicity (Kleemann et al., 2012; O’Connell et al., 2012).

Recently, the genomes of more than 20 Colletotrichum species have been sequenced (O’Connell et al., 2012; Alkan et al., 2013; Gan et al., 2013, 2016, 2017; Baroncelli et al., 2014a,b, 2016; Hacquard et al., 2016; Han et al., 2016; Hiruma et al., 2016; Queiroz et al., 2017), revealing significant diversity in genome architecture and gene content. While most studies have focused on comparisons of distantly related lineages, they also highlight the necessity for higher resolution taxonomic sampling to better understand the evolution of fungal genomes and their possible associations with phenotypic traits such as host range, pathogenic lifestyle, and reproductive strategy. In this context, the C. acutatum species complex serves as an excellent model system, offering a variety of closely related evolutionary lineages with different phenotypic characteristics. An example of this is the switch between mono- and dicotyledonous hosts that occurred in clade 5 (Figure 1). Comparative genomics and transcriptomics of late-diverging species adapted to different hosts may enhance our understanding of the genomic bases involved in host switching. Another notable case is the host specialization of certain lineages, such as C. lupini. The biological diversity of the C. acutatum species complex, coupled with the presence of closely related species exhibiting varied characteristics such as host range, mating behavior, and spectrum, makes C. acutatum a suitable model for investigating genomic signatures associated with changes in crucial phenotypic traits of fungal plants.

Strawberry anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) is one of the main limiting factors for the strawberry production industry worldwide, including Iran. Due to restrictions associated with fungicide applications, their adverse environmental effects, and the potential development of resistance among fungal strains, the use of resistant cultivars is considered the most effective method for managing this disease. This study evaluated the reactions of 25 commercial strawberry cultivars against the fungus Colletotrichum nymphaeae, which causes AFR, using fruit, leaf, and crown-based assays. Results indicated that the cultivars exhibited varying reactions to the disease, depending on the inoculation of their leaves, fruits, and crowns with C. nymphaeae PET1 under in vivo and greenhouse conditions. The fruit-based assay was determined to be a better indicator of susceptibility to AFR due to the nature of the disease. Overall, 'Blakemore' and 'Kurdistan' cultivars showed significantly higher resistance compared to others, except for 'Aliso', 'Mrak', 'Diamant', 'Yallova', 'New Kurdistan', 'Mac Donance', and 'Ten Beauty'. Conversely, the 'Gaviota' cultivar was found to be significantly the most susceptible, aside from 'Camarosa'. The commonly grown commercial cultivars in Iran, including 'Camarosa', 'Paros', 'Pajaro', and 'Queen Eliza', were categorized as susceptible to highly susceptible in this study. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study evaluating the reaction of commercial strawberry cultivars to C. nymphaeae causing strawberry AFR.

Strawberries (Fragaria×ananassa Duch.) are a widely cultivated hybrid species within the Rosaceae family, renowned for their fruit. They are increasingly significant for the agricultural economic development of countries like Iran, particularly in the Kurdistan province, which leads in strawberry production, predominantly under open-field conditions (Tehranifar and Sarsaefi, 2002). Various biotic and abiotic factors contribute to the decline in strawberry production globally. Notably, over 100 fungal species can invade strawberry plants, with approximately one-third causing serious diseases on different plant parts (Martin and others).

In this study, most commercial cultivars, including ‘Paros’, ‘Queen Eliza’, ‘N. Selva’, and ‘Camarosa’, commonly grown in strawberry fields in Iran, were categorized as susceptible. Therefore, deploying relatively resistant cultivars such as ‘Blackmore’, ‘Aliso’, ‘Mark’, ‘Diamant’, and ‘Yallova’ could be effective in preventing disease development in regions where the disease is endemic. Additionally, cultivars with relative resistance may be crossed with commercial cultivars in breeding programs to improve and develop resistant varieties. To the best of our knowledge, this study represents the first attempt to evaluate the reaction of certain commercial strawberry cultivars against Colletotrichum nymphaeae, which causes strawberry AFR.

Many of the species recognized in this work remain poorly understood in terms of their pathogenicity and host preference. This is partly due to a lack of certainty about the biological relationships between the fungi and the plants from which they were isolated. Species that are pathogenic on one host can also be isolated from others following opportunistic colonization of senescing tissue, as illustrated by the example of C. salicis discussed by Johnston (2000) under the name Glomerella miyabeana. The multiple Colletotrichum species associated with a single host likely exhibit a variety of life strategies: primary pathogens of healthy tissue, species capable of invading and causing minor disease when the host plant is under stress, species that develop latent infections and only fruit after the senescence of host tissue or ripening of host fruit, and endophytic species that sporulate only following host tissue death. The combination of these distinct life strategies, the fact that several Colletotrichum species may establish on a single host, and the ability of most of these species to also establish on a range of other hosts contribute significantly to the confusion surrounding species limits within Colletotrichum.

Colletotrichum is one of the most important genera of plant pathogenic fungi worldwide, causing disease symptoms commonly known as anthracnose on a wide range of important crops, fruits, and ornamental plants (Bailey et al., 1992). Notable species include Colletotrichum lindemuthianum, C. gloeosporioides, C. acutatum, C. falcatum, C. nupharicola, and C. nymphaeae. Some plant pathogenic species are significant for quarantine because they could be introduced into regions where the disease is not present (Farr et al., 2006). The taxonomy and phylogeny of the genus Colletotrichum remain confusing (Hyde et al., 2009; Cai et al., 2009). Historically, if anthracnose was found on a host for which there were no prior records of that fungus-host relationship, the species was interpreted as new and formally described (Cannon et al., 2000). This practice was later rejected (von Arx, 1957; Sutton, 1980; Baxter et al., 1983), yet new species are still occasionally described in Colletotrichum (Sivanesan et al., 1993; Nakanura et al., 2006; Liu et al., 2007). Currently, more than 688 epithets are listed in Index Fungorum (www.indexfungorum.org/names/names.asp). Based on a morphological study, von Arx (1957) included more than 600 synonyms under C. gloeosporioides and 84 synonyms under C. dematium. Sutton (1992) listed 39 accepted species in Colletotrichum, each with a brief description. In recent years, molecular tools have been used to infer the evolutionary relationships of Colletotrichum species. Some species have been segregated from the C. gloeosporioides complex based on nu-rDNA ITS sequence data and morphological characteristics, such as C. boninense.

However, clade-based calibration can also provide advantages. Anthracnose diseases are often attributed to several Colletotrichum species within the same clade, depending on the region. For example, the main causal agents of olive anthracnose are found in the acutatum clade, with C. godetiae being dominant in Spain, Italy, Greece, and Tunisia; C. nymphaeae prevalent in Portugal; and C. oriniae predominant in California (Moral et al., 2021). Furthermore, accurate identification of Colletotrichum species necessitates molecular analysis of multiple DNA regions (Damm et al., 2009; Damm et al., 2012; Weir et al., 2012; Damm et al., 2013; Damm et al., 2014). Since species within the same clade often exhibit similar environmental requirements (Salotti et al., 2022), a clade-based calibration may help address knowledge gaps regarding individual Colletotrichum species, facilitate practical model usage when species identification is challenging due to capacity or economic limitations, and enable predictions across a diverse range of hosts and climatic conditions.

Colletotrichum spp. often cause anthracnose disease in herbaceous or woody plants in tropical and subtropical regions (Cannon et al. 2012). The genus Colletotrichum is one of the eight major plant pathogens worldwide (Dean et al. 2012). Three species or species complexes of Colletotrichum have been reported to cause anthracnose in strawberries: the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex, Colletotrichum fragariae, and the Colletotrichum acutatum complex (Denoyes-Rothan et al. 2003). The C. gloeosporioides complex is found worldwide and has a wide range of hosts, whereas C. acutatum and C. fragariae have narrower host ranges (MacKenzie et al. 2008). Although a few C. acutatum infections in Chinese strawberries have been reported, the primary species affecting strawberries in China are believed to be C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (Buddie et al. 1999; Han et al. 2016).

Three species have been documented as causal agents of strawberry anthracnose: Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, C. fragariae, and C. acutatum (Denoyes-Rothan et al. 2003). The anthracnose disease caused by Colletotrichum spp. impacts a wide variety of woody and herbaceous plants, particularly tropical and subtropical crops and fruit trees (Cannon et al. 2012; Freeman et al. 1998; Hyde et al. 2009; Sutton 1992; Wikee et al. 2011). The genus has recently been recognized as the world's eighth most important group of plant-pathogenic fungi due to its scientific and economic significance (Dean et al. 2012). However, the identification of Colletotrichum spp. has historically been challenging. Single-gene phylogenetic analyses have often failed to accurately delineate species (Hyde et al. 2009). Ko Ko et al. Understanding of Colletotrichum spp. has significantly advanced through these molecular approaches.

Colletotrichum Corda is one of the most economically important genera of fungi, responsible for anthracnose and other diseases affecting a wide range of plant species (Sutton, 1980; Hyde et al., 2009). The need for species recognition is therefore a significant practical concern in the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species (Shenoy et al., 2007). However, considerable difficulties have arisen in Colletotrichum systematics due to the lack of reliable morphological features, which makes species boundaries ambiguous and confusing. Traditionally, many Colletotrichum species have been named after their host, suggesting host specificity among species.

retrieved_context: Present and Future Management of Anthracnose: Fungicides, including chemicals such as benzimidazoles (e.g., thiabendazole, benomyl, and carbendazim) and sterol inhibitors (e.g., imazalil, prochloraz, and propiconazole), have been used effectively to control anthracnose disease in banana, mango, papaya, and avocado plants [140]. Benzimidazoles are commonly applied as dips or sprays to inhibit the anthracnose-causing fungus, Colletotrichum spp. [141], but the large-scale and continuous use of fungicides has led to the development of fungal resistance. For instance, benzimidazole-resistant Colletotrichum has been detected in mangoes and bananas [140]. Additionally, the excessive use of fungicides negatively impacts human health and the environment, as chemical residues often contaminate soil and water [142]. Biocontrol offers an alternative, non-toxic method for managing fruit crop anthracnose. Biocontrol agents, such as antagonistic microbes including yeast, bacteria, and filamentous fungi (particularly Trichoderma spp.), have shown promising results and are gaining popularity for their direct application to fruit surfaces post-harvest [143].

Until highly resistant cultivars are available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to reduce losses due to anthracnose. The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be due to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population. For example, benomyl effectively reduced the incidence of anthracnose crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971) and was used intensively by strawberry growers for years to control anthracnose and other diseases. However, the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, developed resistance to it and other benzimidazole fungicides (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993), rendering benomyl ineffective for anthracnose control in strawberry fields.

There is an urgent need for multi- and single-site fungicide alternatives effective against anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and production fields. The antifungal antibiotic natamycin, widely used as a natural mold inhibitor in food products, has shown promise in controlling anthracnose root and crown infections caused by C. acutatum on strawberry transplants (Cordova et al. 2017; Haack et al. 2018). Similarly, fluazinam, a single-site respiration inhibitor fungicide from FRAC group 29, has demonstrated significant control of anthracnose fruit rot (Mertely et al. 2018). A request has been submitted through the Interregional Research Project Number 4 for its registration for nursery use only. Reducing the overlap of the same modes of action used during nursery and fruit production phases could help extend the lifespan of single-site fungicides at high risk of resistance.

For the management of anthracnose crown rot, water washing or fungicide treatments of bare-root transplants have been utilized in the nursery or immediately before planting in production fields (Daugovish et al., 2009; Freeman et al., 1997). Running water effectively removes soil from root and crown tissues, potentially eliminating inoculum, but it does not control any infections already present (Koike et al., 2008). Pre-plant fungicide dips have been shown to decrease anthracnose crown rot; however, only two products are currently registered for this use in the United States. The single-site mode of action quinone outside inhibitor (QoI), azoxystrobin, has been widely used as a preplant dip and as a foliar treatment for managing anthracnose and other fungal diseases (Bartlett et al., 2002; Koike et al., 2008; Turechek et al., 2006). Resistance has been reported against this fungicide group in Colletotrichum acutatum populations from strawberries in Florida (Forcelini et al., 2016). During the 2015-16 California nursery crown rot outbreak, growers reported reduced efficacy of azoxystrobin dips, suggesting that resistance may also be present in California (K. Ivors, unpublished). A premixed product of the anilinopyrimidine cyprodinil and the phenylpyrrole fludioxonil is also registered, but phytotoxicity and stunting of plants have been reported under certain environmental conditions or following off-label exposure (G. Holmes, unpublished).

In this paper, we determined the sensitivities of C. gloeosporioides s.s. isolates to various fungicides, including difenoconazole, tebuconazole, flusilazole, and carbendazim. Although the number of isolates was relatively limited, the results indicated differences in resistance ratios to carbendazim and tebuconazole among all isolates. The resistance ratios to carbendazim ranged from 1 to 87.3, while those for tebuconazole ranged from 1 to 51.6. Isolates SL-31, SL-34, SL-30, and SL-37, collected from Shangluo County, Shaanxi Province, showed resistance ratios to tebuconazole of 1, 6, 16.2, and 38.9, respectively. Carbendazim and tebuconazole are extensively used to control walnut anthracnose disease, and the observed differences in sensitivities may reflect the local frequency of fungicide usage. Additionally, the sensitivities of C. gloeosporioides and C. acutatum to carbendazim differed (Cao et al. 2017). Our study indicated that isolates of C. gloeosporioides s.s. exhibited varying sensitivities to carbendazim. These results reflect the sensitivities of C. gloeosporioides s.s. causing walnut anthracnose to fungicides to some extent. To enhance control effectiveness, it is essential for practitioners to ascertain the sensitivities of isolates to fungicides. Based on the EC50 values and resistance ratios, difenoconazole and flusilazole are expected to provide better control than carbendazim and tebuconazole in a given plantation. However, these efficacies need to be validated with more field trials in the future. For effective control of walnut anthracnose, accurate identification of the pathogen is crucial. It is also necessary to determine the fungicide sensitivities of different isolates within the same fungal taxon. Fungicides should be chosen cautiously for disease management, and those with different mechanisms should be used in rotation.

The failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics may be attributed to the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum species population. Within the genus Colletotrichum, C. gloeosporioides s.l. is the most diversified complex, comprising as many as 57 species. This complex has been considered a heterogeneous species aggregate affecting over 700 plant species (O'Connell et al. 2012; Talhinhas and Baroncelli 2021; Farr and Rossman 2022). The most prevalent species in Chinese strawberry fields, C. siamense and C. fructicola, belong to C. gloeosporioides s.l. They are the two most frequently occurring Colletotrichum species globally, with significantly more records in Asia compared to other continents. Both species can affect more than 70 genera of hosts widely distributed across the phylogenetic tree of angiosperms. Compared to C. fructicola, C. siamense infects significantly more plants, including one gymnosperm. Notably, some Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries can also infect members of other kingdoms beyond plant hosts. For instance, the prevalent C. siamense in strawberry fields has been reported as a human pathogen, causing skin lesions in immunocompromised individuals (Werbel et al. 2019). However, most of these models are simple, considering only one component of the pathogen life cycle—primarily conidial infection—and focus on a single Colletotrichum species or crop. In contrast, mechanistic models have a flexible structure, high explanatory ability, and the capability to make predictions across a wide range of agricultural contexts. Integrated pest management (IPM) strategies for Colletotrichum spp. encompass cultural, biological, and chemical control measures. Cultural control practices include producing disease-free propagating materials, avoiding overhead irrigation, minimizing rain splashing through mulching, and managing weeds (Coelho et al., 2008; Saxena et al., 2016). It is also recommended to remove infected crop residues and any mummified or rotten fruits to reduce inoculum sources and disease spread.

Conversely, nitrate-nitrogen (Ca(NO3)2·4H2O) and CuSO4·5H2O reduced disease severity. Low rates of NH4NO3 (39 to 79 mg·L–1 N) were beneficial, but levels above 100 mg·L–1 N exacerbated the issue. The form of nitrogen significantly influenced both the severity of Fusarium crown and root rot and the growth of tomato seedlings in a soilless rockwool system (Fig. 1). Increasing concentrations of nitrate-N reduced disease severity and improved plant growth compared to ammonium forms. Both ammonium sulfate and ammonium chloride produced similar responses, indicating that NH4+ was the harmful component (Fig. 1). Ammonium nitrate has been reported to either have no effect on Fusarium diseases or to increase disease severity, similar to ammonium-N (Jones et al., 1989; Schneider, 1985). While this was generally true for Fusarium crown and root rot, testing a range of concentrations revealed that at low concentrations (10 to 100 mg·L–1 N), ammonium nitrate reduced disease similarly to nitrate-N (Figs. 1D, 2D). However, the negative influence of the NH4+ ion became apparent at concentrations above 125 mg·L–1 N (Figs. 1D, 2D). At higher concentrations, seedlings might have lacked sufficient available carbohydrates to convert the excess ammonium, which is toxic for tomato seedlings (Woltz et al., 1992), into nontoxic amino acids (Pate, 1973). Nitrates have long been recognized for their role in reducing seedling diseases caused by Rhizoctonia solani (Huber and Watson, 1974); however, contradictory results have been reported for Fusarium crown and root rot. Mihuta-Grimm et al. Jarvis and Thorpe (1980) found no effect of nitrogen form (with total N applied unspecified) on disease or yield when adequate lime was provided to counteract potential pH effects. In fact, the differential effect of nitrogen form on pH is a significant mechanism for suppressing many soilborne pathogens (Huber and Watson, 1974). In contrast, Woltz et al. (1992) reported differences between nitrate and ammonium-N (each at 225 mg·L–1).

Primary inoculum consists of fresh conidia produced in acervuli under favorable conditions of temperature (10 to 30°C for most clades) and moisture (e.g., wetness periods longer than 6 hours) from overwintered sources throughout the cropping season (Moral and Trapero, 2012; Stensvand et al., 2017; Everett et al., 2018). The germ tubes then produce appressoria, which form infection pegs that penetrate the host cuticle and epidermal cell walls (Perfect et al., 1999). In some cases, the pathogen has a quiescent phase (Peres et al., 2005; Prusky et al., 2013), with the switch to the necrotrophic phase occurring only when host tissue and environmental conditions favor the continuation of the infection cycle. Except for a few species that exist entirely as endophytes, most Colletotrichum species develop a necrotrophic stage at some point in their life cycle (Prusky et al., 2013).

Transplants are considered the main source of primary inoculum, but the complete epidemiology of Colletotrichum spp. on strawberries in China remains unclear.

retrieved_context: Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.

Three species have been reported as causal agents of strawberry anthracnose: Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. (teleomorph Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk). These species cause similar symptoms on strawberries, including crown rot, fruit rot, and stolon lesions. In Europe, C. acutatum is the most prevalent species causing anthracnose, while C. gloeosporioides is found only occasionally, and C. fragariae has not yet been observed.

The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.

Abril, M. 2001. Ultrastructural study of anthracnose infection of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) petiole and stolon by Colletotrichum acutatum and Colletotrichum fragariae. M.S. thesis. University of Southern Mississippi.

Colletotrichum fragariae and Colletotrichum acutatum are known to cause anthracnose diseases in strawberries. C. fragariae was initially assumed to be the causal agent of strawberry anthracnose in the United States until 1986, when Smith and Black reported the presence of C. acutatum on strawberries in the United States. This fungus had previously been documented as causing anthracnose fruit rot of strawberries in Queensland, Australia (Simmonds, 1965); however, it had likely existed in the United States for some time under the name Gloeosporium spp. (Maas, 1984).

The fungi Colletotrichum fragariae and Colletotrichum acutatum cause anthracnose diseases in strawberries. C. fragariae was originally assumed to be the sole causal agent of strawberry anthracnose in the United States until 1986, when Smith and Black reported the presence of C. acutatum on strawberries in the U.S. This fungus had previously been reported to cause anthracnose fruit rot in Queensland, Australia (Simmonds, 1965); however, it may have been present in the U.S. for some time under the name Gloeosporium spp. (Maas, 1984).

Colletotrichum is a genus of fungi that often causes anthracnose disease. In Japan and elsewhere, strawberry anthracnose has been attributed to infections by Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, which caused at least one major epidemic of anthracnose crown rot in the United States during the 1970s (Smith 2008; Suzuki et al. 2010). Anthracnose disease is a major problem in the Japanese strawberry cultivation industry, where infections are thought to be spread primarily through latently infected plants and infected plant material (Suzuki et al. 2010). The presence of even one infected plant can result in the infection of an entire field, highlighting the importance of early detection and classification.

The anthracnose pathogen, Colletotrichum acutatum J. H. Simmonds, poses a serious threat to strawberry production worldwide. All parts of the strawberry plant are susceptible to infection; however, fruit rot is particularly damaging in production fields, leading to significant yield losses. Anthracnose development in strawberry nurseries not only reduces daughter plant production but also has serious consequences for pathogen dissemination on contaminated transplants. Once C. acutatum is introduced into production fields, managing disease outbreaks becomes challenging, as available control measures are only partially effective. Consequently, the use of pathogen-free propagation material is highly desirable, though implementation is difficult due to the lack of adequate detection and certification schemes for C. acutatum on symptomless plants.

The difficulty in controlling anthracnose crown rot arises from the fact that Colletotrichum spp. can kill strawberry plants after aggressively invading crown tissue, with a long latent period during which no symptoms are visible. Additionally, there are no long-term effective fungicides available, and the diverse origins of the causal agents are unpredictable (Peres et al., 2017; Forcelini and Peres, 2018; Hirayama et al., 2018). Furthermore, Colletotrichum spp. can be dispersed from asymptomatic plants over long distances, while relevant quarantine measures for strawberry trade are lacking in China. Recognizing the causal agents is a prerequisite for disease control. Initially, identification largely depended on morphological observation and virulence tests. Repeated in vitro subculturing of microbes can alter both their morphology and virulence. The fact that morphological characteristics can vary based on host choice or environmental conditions poses a significant concern for fungal identification. Strawberry anthracnose was first reported nearly a century ago (Brooks, 1931). Through PCR and DNA sequencing techniques, researchers have clarified the genetic distinctions among Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, categorizing pathogens of worldwide origin into C. acutatum, C. fragariae, and C. gloeosporioides (Martínez-Culebras et al., 2000, 2003). However, ambiguously annotated data for Colletotrichum species frequently appear in GenBank, leading to confusion (Nilsson et al., 2006; Hyde et al., 2009). The emergence of multi-locus phylogeny has significantly aided in the identification of fungal species. Many pathologists and biologists have greatly expanded knowledge of Colletotrichum systematics (Cannon et al., 2012; Damm et al., 2012a, b; Weir et al., 2012), providing a solid foundation for future research. A landmark study corrected many synonymous names and offered a valuable reference for understanding Colletotrichum pathogens (Hyde et al., 2014). The delineation of Colletotrichum species and the description of new species continue to progress with the advent of novel technologies such as whole genome sequencing (Jayawardena et al., 2020, 2021; Bhunjun et al., 2021; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021).

Strawberry anthracnose was first reported in China in 1990 (Hu, 1990). Shao (1992) documented the first instance of strawberry anthracnose in Shanghai, identifying the pathogen as Colletotrichum acutatum (Dai et al., 2006). Zhang et al. (2007) expanded on these findings by identifying C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (syn. C. theobromicola) as causal agents based on morphological characteristics. Ren et al. (2008, 2011) concluded that these three species are the main pathogens causing anthracnose in strawberries in China. Crown rot represents the most severe disease issue in many strawberry-producing regions of China (Ren et al., 2008). In the Zhejiang region, nearly 50% of seedling deaths in nurseries and over 40% yield losses in strawberry fields have been recorded (Xie et al., 2010). In 2009, the yield of greenhouse-cultivated strawberries in Donggang City, Liaoning Province, was reduced by over 10% due to crown rot (Wang, 2013). The average incidence of crown rot in greenhouses in Hubei Province was 41.7% in 2011 (Xiang et al., 2012). However, most studies conducted in China regarding this disease have primarily relied on morphological and single-gene (mainly ITS) analysis (Dai et al., 2006; Ren et al., 2008, 2011). Due to overlapping characteristics, species delimitation based solely on morphology is challenging in this genus. Employing multi-gene analysis alongside morphology can provide better resolution (Cai et al., 2009; Hyde et al., 2014). Therefore, the objective of this study was to identify the pathogens responsible for strawberry anthracnose in China using a morphological and multi-gene approach.

query: Why is it important to confirm pathogenicity using verified Colletotrichum species?
retrieved_context: Pathogenicity testing is highlighted as a crucial step to determine whether a specific Colletotrichum species is host-specific or has a broader host range. Host-specific taxa may have limited distributions, which carry significant biosecurity implications. Conversely, species with a wide host range may be more cosmopolitan and potentially opportunistic pathogens. Koch’s postulates have been applied to confirm the pathogenicity of various Colletotrichum isolates. For instance, studies have shown that C. acutatum causes Rhododendron anthracnose, while C. boninense was implicated in leaf infections of Euonymus. New species descriptions occasionally include data on pathogenicity testing, although this is not always the case. Further pathogenicity research is encouraged to validate findings across verified Colletotrichum species.

Jayawardena RS, Hyde KD, Jeewon R, Liu XH, Liu M, Yan JY. (2016). Why is it Important to Correctly Name Colletotrichum Species? Mycosphere (This issue - [http://doi 10.5943/mycosphere/si/1c/1](http://doi 10.5943/mycosphere/si/1c/1)).

Disentangling species complexes within the Colletotrichum genus presents a significant challenge for taxonomists. Given the global importance of this genus, primarily consisting of plant pathogens, it is critical to accurately identify species and/or pathotypes to enhance biosecurity and disease control efforts. Traditional methods of species identification have relied on morphological, cultural, and host-preference criteria. However, these methods often prove unreliable, leading to unresolved taxonomic issues. As stated by Sutton (1992), relying solely on morphology is insufficient for improving the systematics of species complexes like C. gloeosporioides.

Previous reports indicated that the pathogenicity of most identified Colletotrichum species associated with pear anthracnose—including C. aenigma, C. fructicola, C. acutatum, C. fioriniae, C. pyricola, and C. salicis—showed no pathogenicity to pear fruits (P. bretschneideri cv. Huangguan) under unwounded conditions up to 30 dpi. These findings reveal a clear organ specificity regarding the pathogenicity of some isolates.

Species descriptions will become standardized, and if morphological characters prove to be totally inadequate, they may be eliminated altogether. Pathogenicity testing will become essential to establish the biological role of these fungi. Colletotrichum has particular biosecurity importance, and until the genus becomes better defined, we suggest that plant quarantine authorities delay taking imprudent action. Many Colletotrichum species are proving to be widespread on a broad range of hosts, with some functioning as endophytes as well as pathogens. Many recently described species (e.g., in Prihastuti et al., 2009; Yang et al., 2009) are found to be prevalent on a variety of unrelated hosts, acting as endophytes, epiphytes, pathogens, or weak and opportunistic pathogens.

Many of the species recognized in this work remain poorly understood in terms of their pathogenicity and host preference. This is partly due to a lack of certainty about the biological relationships between the fungi and the plants from which they were isolated. Species that are pathogenic on one host can also be isolated from others following opportunistic colonization of senescing tissue, as illustrated by the example of C. salicis discussed by Johnston (2000) under the name Glomerella miyabeana. The multiple Colletotrichum species associated with a single host likely exhibit a variety of life strategies: primary pathogens of healthy tissue, species capable of invading and causing minor disease when the host plant is under stress, species that develop latent infections and only fruit after the senescence of host tissue or ripening of host fruit, and endophytic species that sporulate only following host tissue death. The combination of these distinct life strategies, the fact that several Colletotrichum species may establish on a single host, and the ability of most of these species to also establish on a range of other hosts contribute significantly to the confusion surrounding species limits within Colletotrichum.

This study underscores the genetic and pathogenic heterogeneity of introduced anthracnose pathogen populations belonging to three distinct Colletotrichum species. It emphasizes the necessity for effective phytosanitary procedures related to pathogen monitoring and characterization to limit the entry of non-native pathogens. Additionally, it highlights the need for reliable and rapid diagnostic tools for ongoing research and practical applications in strawberry anthracnose management. The recent release of the whole genome sequence of C. fioriniae isolated from strawberries, along with newly characterized isolates based on multi-locus sequence and aggressiveness data reported here, provides a valuable platform for further investigations into the genetic basis of C. acutatum sensu lato interactions with strawberries.

query: Was the USDA strawberry breeding program more successful in developing disease-resistant varieties or in improving strawberry flavor and texture?
retrieved_context: In the early 1980s, when anthracnose became a major disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States, the USDA-ARS initiated a breeding program aimed at developing anthracnose-resistant cultivars suitable for the region. This program was established at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982). From 1976 to 1995, over 160,000 progeny from 448 crosses made primarily by G.J. Galletta at Beltsville were screened for anthracnose resistance in the greenhouse at Poplarville, MS.

In the early 1980s, anthracnose became a significant disease affecting strawberries in the southeastern United States. In response, the USDA-ARS established a breeding program to develop anthracnose-resistant cultivars suited to the strawberry-growing regions of this area. This initiative was conducted at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD, in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982).
Smith, B. J. (2006). USDA-ARS strawberry anthracnose resistance breeding program. Acta Hort., 708:463-470.

A solid understanding of host-pathogen interactions is crucial for designing an effective breeding program for disease resistance. This approach is the more cost-effective option for controlling anthracnose in strawberries. Genetic components of resistance to both pathogenicity groups must be integrated to develop a broadly effective resistance, as the dominant resistant gene can be overcome by C. acutatum isolates from pathogenicity group 1 (7). A selection scheme was proposed for breeders, in which the likely quantitative resistance to C. acutatum from pathogenicity group 1 is selected in seedlings at the beginning of the selection process. Later, resistance to pathogenicity group 2, conferred by the dominant gene, is selected after vegetative multiplication of cold-stored plants. Research focused on molecular markers linked to these different resistance components would enhance our understanding of resistance and assist in selecting genitors for anthracnose resistance.

The evaluation of strawberry seedlings and advanced breeding lines from state and private breeding programs continues as an ongoing project. The USDA’s anthracnose-resistance screening procedure has effectively identified resistant genotypes in seedling progenies from the North Carolina State University breeding program, with over 32,000 resistant strawberry seedlings identified between 1998 and 1999 (Ballington et al., 2002).

In this study, most commercial cultivars, including ‘Paros’, ‘Queen Eliza’, ‘N. Selva’, and ‘Camarosa’, commonly grown in strawberry fields in Iran, were categorized as susceptible. Anthracnose disease, caused by C. acutatum, has become one of the major fungal pathogens of strawberry worldwide. In Israel, the fungus was first reported in 1995 and has since spread to most strawberry cultivation areas within the country. Mother plants are commonly infected in the nursery; however, symptoms may develop later during daughter plant establishment, after planting. Such mother plants are considered the primary inoculum source from which the fungus proliferates and then spreads to daughter plants in the nursery, eventually reaching production fields via transplants. While plant infection in the nursery is a significant source of inoculum, there may be additional sources for the dissemination of the fungus and initiation of new epidemics, such as other plant species. Strawberry is cultivated alongside tomato, eggplant, pepper, and other vegetable crops, with various weeds persisting in the vicinity of nurseries and near or within strawberry production fields in Israel. The main objectives of this study were to assess the potential for cross-inoculation, survival, and pathogenicity of C. acutatum on strawberry and other plants that may serve as a primary inoculum source under greenhouse conditions.

Anthracnose is an important disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum spp., which affects foliage, runners, crowns, and fruits (Howard et al., 1992). Three primary fungal pathogens—C. acutatum sensu lato, C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, and C. fragariae—are known to cause anthracnose disease in strawberries (Freeman and Katan, 1997). The crown rot syndrome is characteristic of infections from C. gloeosporioides sensu lato and C. fragariae, while fruit rot is mainly attributed to C. acutatum sensu lato, leading to significant yield losses (Howard et al., 1992). Currently, numerous species are classified under what is now known as the C. acutatum complex, with six species—C. acutatum sensu stricto, C. fioriniae, C. godetiae, C. nymphaeae, C. salicis, and C. simmondsii—identified as associated with strawberry anthracnose worldwide (Damm et al., 2012). Among these, C. nymphaeae is the most prevalent pathogen causing strawberry anthracnose globally, including in Iran (Baroncelli et al., 2015; Karimi et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2019). Currently, no effective chemical control methods exist for managing strawberry anthracnose; available options are limited to preventive treatments applied before fruit production (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 1999). Additionally, concerns about the toxic effects of chemical fungicides on the environment and the development of resistance in fungal strains highlight the need for alternative control strategies. Consequently, utilizing resistant cultivars appears to be the most efficient and practical approach for suppressing anthracnose development. In light of recent anthracnose outbreaks in strawberry fields in the Kurdistan province of Iran (Karimi et al., 2017), and the necessity for appropriate strategies to address this issue, the aim of this study was to evaluate the resistance of several commercial strawberry cultivars to the anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. nymphaeae under in vivo and greenhouse conditions.

Several species of the fungal plant pathogen Colletotrichum cause anthracnose in strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.), a major disease affecting this crop. The principal pathogens known to be responsible for the disease are C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. (teleomorph Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk). Infections of mother plants with C. acutatum, which develop into bud and eventually crown rot, lead to the collapse and death of the plant. In the nursery, lesions form on stolons, girdling the runners and resulting in the wilting and death of unrooted daughter plants distal to the lesions. The related pathogens C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae cause symptoms similar to those caused by C. acutatum. Infected transplants can spread the disease from the nursery to the field, where typical anthracnose symptoms manifest as irregular black leaf spots, crown rot, flower blight, and fruit rot. Considerable yield loss can occur under appropriate environmental and cultural conditions.

Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum species is one of the most destructive diseases affecting strawberry production worldwide. Fungi of the genus Colletotrichum, which are ancient and co-evolved with flowering plants, rank eighth among the ten most economically important fungal pathogens and have diversified to adapt to various hosts. Since its first report in the United States in 1931, strawberry anthracnose has spread globally, resulting in devastating economic, social, and ecological consequences. In many ways, producing organic strawberries is largely impractical because of this disease. Colletotrichum species pathogenic to strawberries have been extensively characterized. This review aims to provide an accurate inventory of these species by revisiting their discovery history over the past 90 years. A total of 23 Colletotrichum species, clustered into five species complexes and two singleton taxa, have been accepted as strawberry pathogens with a global occurrence illustrated. The relative prevalence of distinct Colletotrichum species associated with strawberries has been systematically analyzed in China. Finally, the host range of the two prevailing species, C. fructicola and C. siamense, which cause significant damage globally, is summarized, with the goal of improving diagnostic accuracy and anthracnose management in agricultural ecosystems.

The difficulty in controlling anthracnose crown rot arises from the fact that Colletotrichum spp. can kill strawberry plants after aggressively invading crown tissue, with a long latent period during which no symptoms are visible. Additionally, there are no long-term effective fungicides available, and the diverse origins of the causal agents are unpredictable (Peres et al., 2017; Forcelini and Peres, 2018; Hirayama et al., 2018). Furthermore, Colletotrichum spp. can be dispersed from asymptomatic plants over long distances, while relevant quarantine measures for strawberry trade are lacking in China. Recognizing the causal agents is a prerequisite for disease control. Initially, identification largely depended on morphological observation and virulence tests. Repeated in vitro subculturing of microbes can alter both their morphology and virulence. The fact that morphological characteristics can vary based on host choice or environmental conditions poses a significant concern for fungal identification. Strawberry anthracnose was first reported nearly a century ago (Brooks, 1931). Through PCR and DNA sequencing techniques, researchers have clarified the genetic distinctions among Colletotrichum spp. associated with strawberries, categorizing pathogens of worldwide origin into C. acutatum, C. fragariae, and C. gloeosporioides (Martínez-Culebras et al., 2000, 2003). However, ambiguously annotated data for Colletotrichum species frequently appear in GenBank, leading to confusion (Nilsson et al., 2006; Hyde et al., 2009). The emergence of multi-locus phylogeny has significantly aided in the identification of fungal species. Many pathologists and biologists have greatly expanded knowledge of Colletotrichum systematics (Cannon et al., 2012; Damm et al., 2012a, b; Weir et al., 2012), providing a solid foundation for future research. A landmark study corrected many synonymous names and offered a valuable reference for understanding Colletotrichum pathogens (Hyde et al., 2014). The delineation of Colletotrichum species and the description of new species continue to progress with the advent of novel technologies such as whole genome sequencing (Jayawardena et al., 2020, 2021; Bhunjun et al., 2021; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021).

The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberries caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" continues to be used as a general term to identify all diseases of strawberries caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been reported to be caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. (the teleomorph of Cromereilla cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. The latter species only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.

The fungi Colletotrichum fragariae and Colletotrichum acutatum cause anthracnose diseases in strawberries. C. fragariae was originally assumed to be the sole causal agent of strawberry anthracnose in the United States until 1986, when Smith and Black reported the presence of C. acutatum on strawberries in the U.S. This fungus had previously been reported to cause anthracnose fruit rot in Queensland, Australia (Simmonds, 1965); however, it may have been present in the U.S. for some time under the name Gloeosporium spp. (Maas, 1984).

Anthracnose is a key limiting factor for strawberry production in Taiwan and many other regions. Outbreaks of anthracnose in strawberry nurseries and fields have caused yield losses of up to 50-80%. This study demonstrated the diversity of pathogenic Colletotrichum species associated with strawberry in Taiwan. The findings provide precise information about pathogen identity, which is valuable for screening resistant varieties and developing effective disease management strategies. Regardless of whether inoculated on wounded or non-wounded leaves, the predominant pathogen C. siamense caused larger lesions at 30°C than at 25°C, which is significant in subtropical Taiwan and similar areas. No significant difference was observed between the mycelial growth rates of C. siamense at 25°C, 28°C, and 30°C; hence, the higher disease severity at 30°C may be due to reduced resistance of strawberry plants to anthracnose at elevated temperatures. In Taiwan, the susceptible cultivar Taoyuan No. 1 has been widely cultivated for over 30 years. Developing temperature-independent resistant cultivars will be crucial for strawberry breeding programs in Taiwan and other tropical and subtropical regions. Future work will focus on monitoring pathogen population changes, investigating fungicide sensitivity levels of different Colletotrichum species, and developing molecular detection methods to assist in producing strawberry seedlings free of latent infection by major Colletotrichum species.

Other treatments, including prochloraz-Zn/folpet (50.6% control), propiconazole (33.8% control), and difenoconazole (28.8% control), were less effective than prochloraz-Zn and heat treatment. Prochloraz-Mn and prochloraz-Zn were the most effective in reducing transplant mortality. In 1995, prochloraz-Mn reduced mortality by 93.3%, while in 1996, reductions were 86.8% for prochloraz-Mn and 93.1% for prochloraz-Zn, with no significant differences between them. Prochloraz-Zn/folpet, propiconazole, and difenoconazole were less effective than prochloraz alone.
